questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of increasing swelling around his eyes for the past 3 days. During this period, he has had frothy light yellow urine. He had a sore throat 12 days ago. He appears tired. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital edema and pitting edema of the lower extremities. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following findings on urinalysis is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epithelial casts in the urine sediment are the result of a process that causes death of the renal tubule epithelium. Consequently, the epithelial cells slough off into the lumen and appear as casts. Possible etiologies include acute tubular necrosis (e.g., due to prolonged hypotension/renal infarction or administration of a nephrotoxic drug), toxin ingestion, or infection with cytomegalovirus. This patient's history does not support any of these causes, making this answer unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

WBC casts in urinary sediment are strongly associated with pyelonephritis, although they are not pathognomonic. This patient is afebrile and has no history that might indicate serious urinary tract infection. Other causes of WBC casts include interstitial nephritis or poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. Interstitial nephritis is most commonly associated with a hypersensitivity reaction to NSAIDs, penicillins, or sulfa drugs, none of which have been taken by the patient. While this patient's history of a sore throat could indicate he has poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, this condition causes nephritic rather than nephrotic syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of urine sediment (phase-contrast microscopy; high magnification)

White blood cell (WBC) casts (blue overlay) contain leukocytes (examples outlined in yellow) that are compressed in a matrix. Sharp margins are characteristic of WBC casts, differentiating them from randomly assembled leukocyte conglomerates.

C) INCORRECT:

Waxy casts are most often seen in cases of chronic kidney disease because they can best form in low urine flow states. Although also associated with nephrotic syndrome, waxy casts are observed only in long-standing nephrotic range proteinuria. This patient is very unlikely to have chronic nephrotic syndrome because his symptoms began only 3 days ago.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of urine sediment (high magnification)

Degenerating granular casts are described as waxy casts, which typically have a homogeneous, smooth, yellowish appearance and show clearly defined, dark borders with blunt and broken-off ends. They are more brittle and fragile in comparison with other casts. The lower figure shows a segmented example, where sharp indentations are easily recognizable.

Waxy casts are found in the urine sediment of patients with chronic kidney failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyaline casts are the most commonly observed casts in urine sediment analysis. Their presence is nonspecific. They are commonly seen in healthy individuals who have recently exercised vigorously or been dehydrated.
Image Description:

Urine sediment microscopy (left: unstained; right: Sternheimer stain, 400x magnification)

Left: A translucent, cylindrical, acellular structure is seen.
Right: The stain has enhanced the protein matrix, which appears light blue.

These features are typical of hyaline casts, which are composed of a mucoprotein matrix of Tamm-Horsfall protein and contain neither cells nor debris.

Hyaline casts are a nonspecific finding on urinalysis as they are also seen in healthy individuals.

E) INCORRECT:

Red blood cells in urinary sediment are always abnormal. Their presence indicates glomerulonephritis (GN) and is caused by the congregation of proteins and RBCs inside the tubules. In this patient, GN might be secondary to his throat infection (poststreptococcal GN). Clinically, GN results in nephritic syndrome with red or cola-colored urine and much milder edema due to the relatively limited loss of albumin (< 3.5 g/24 h). This patient has yellow urine and likely nephrotic syndrome, so RBC casts would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of urine sediment (high magnification)

A cast consisting of multiple red blood cells is visible.

RBC casts are typically seen in patients with glomerular damage (e.g., glomerulonephritis).

F) CORRECT:

Fatty casts are very common in the urinary sediment of patients with nephrotic syndrome. Massive proteinuria (> 3.5 g/24 h) results in low serum albumin, which reduces capillary oncotic pressure, thereby causing edema secondary to fluid leaking into tissue. Consequently, the liver increases all synthetic activity (involving albumin as well as other macromolecules, such as lipids) to compensate. Some of these excess lipids are reabsorbed by the proximal tubular epithelial cells. Once the cytoplasm becomes engorged, chunks of the cell can slough off into the tubular lumen, leading to the classic fatty casts on urinary sediment.

Patients with nephrotic syndrome are at high risk of developing infections (due to urinary loss of IgG), hypocalcemia (due to vitamin D deficiency), and venous thrombus formation (due to urinary loss of antithrombin III and loss of fluid into the extravascular space).
Image Description:

Polarized light micrograph of lyotropic liquid crystals

These Lα liquid crystals have a characteristic Maltese cross appearance (examples indicated by green overlay) under polarized light. Fatty casts from urinary sediment have the same appearance under polarized light.

G) INCORRECT:

Muddy brown casts are a type of granular cast most often associated with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) that originate from the fusion of plasma proteins shed from damaged epithelial cells of the tubule lining. This patient's history is not consistent with any conditions that predispose to ATN (e.g., prolonged hypotension/renal infarction, toxin ingestion, or adverse effect of nephrotoxic drugs), making this finding much less likely. ATN would also not explain his nephrotic syndrome.
Image Description:

Urine sediment microscopy (unstained, 400x magnification)

The unstained urine sediment shows a translucent structure with multiple granules embedded in the hyaline matrix.

This is the typical presentation of a granular cast, which can be found e.g. in proteinuria.
questions.hint: Edema in combination with frothy urine is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease, which is most likely this child's diagnosis, especially considering his recent pharyngitis.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of facial swelling that started 5 days ago. Two weeks ago, he had a sore throat that resolved spontaneously. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 94/67 mm Hg. Examination shows pitting edema of the upper and lower extremities as well as periorbital edema. The abdomen is mildly distended. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Serum



 Albumin

2.1 g/dL


 Total cholesterol

290 mg/dL


 Triglycerides
210 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
negative


 Glucose
negative


 Protein

4+


 Leukocyte esterase
negative


A renal biopsy of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy
Subepithelial dense deposits on electron microscopy
Deposits of IgG and C3 at the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluoresence
Linear deposition of anti-GBM antibodies on immunofluorescence
Granular subepithelial deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence
Apple-green birefringence with Congo red stain
Effacement of foot processes of podocytes on light microscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane resulting in a tram-track appearance on electron microscopy is seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), which can be caused by immune complex deposition (associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C) or by overactivation of the alternative complement pathway. MPGN is not commonly seen in children and usually manifests with hematuria.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (PAS stain; high magnification)

The glomerulus shows slightly increased mesangial cellularity (examples indicated by circles) and duplication of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). The latter displays in the form of a double contour of the GBM (tram-track appearance; examples indicated by yellow lines).
As a secondary finding, there is an Angiostrongylus larva within the glomerulus (blue overlay).

Duplication of the GBM is a typical finding in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Mesangial proliferation is seen on light microscopy in IgA nephropathy, which is the most common cause of glomerulonephritis in adults. Additional findings of IgA nephropathy include mesangial IgA deposits on immunofluorescence and mesangial immune complex deposits on electron microscopy. IgA nephropathy usually manifests with a single or recurrent episodes of hematuria and nephritic rather than nephrotic sediment during or immediately after an infection (synpharyngitic glomerulonephritis). While IgA nephropathy can progress to nephrotic syndrome, another underlying condition is much more likely in this child.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

C) INCORRECT:

Subepithelial dense deposits (which results in a spike-and-dome appearance) on electron microscopy are seen in membranous nephropathy, which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in white adults. Additional findings of membranous nephropathy include thickened glomerular capillary loops on light microscopy. Membranous nephropathy is not commonly seen in children.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (Jones silver stain; very high magnification)

Thickening of the basement membrane (indicated by yellow outlines) with spike formation (examples indicated by blue arrowheads) can be seen.

This histopathologic appearance is characteristic of membranous nephropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Deposits of IgG and C3 at the glomerular basement membrane are seen on immunofluorescence in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). This condition is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C. MPGN can also result from overactivation of the alternative complement pathway. It is not commonly seen in children, however, and usually manifests with microscopic hematuria.

E) INCORRECT:

Linear deposition of antiglomerular basement membrane antibodies is seen on immunofluorescence in Goodpasture syndrome. Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that typically manifests in adults, in which antibodies against type IV collagen cause alveolar hemorrhage (resulting in dyspnea and hemoptysis) and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Although Goodpasture syndrome can cause edema and mild proteinuria, as seen here, patients usually present with nephritic sediment.

F) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has minimal change disease (MCD), which manifests without visible changes on light microscopy. In this condition, circulating cytokines can cause effacement of podocytes, which is only visible on electron microscopy. MCD is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (especially < 10 years of age). It may be triggered by a recent infection (as seen in this case) or immunization. MCD responds very well to corticosteroids and has a good prognosis, which is why renal biopsy is usually not indicated for diagnosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tissue obtained from renal biopsy (H&E stain; high magnification)

The basement membrane of the glomerulus is intact, the mesangium does not show proliferation. The capillary lumens are visible and there are no vascular changes.

This is the typical appearance of a glomerulus in minimal change disease.

G) INCORRECT:

Granular subepithelial deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence are seen in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Though PSGN can manifest with edema 1–6 weeks after an infection with group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (potentially the cause of this patient's sore throat), it usually manifests with nephritic sediment rather than nephrotic sediment.
Image Description:

Immunofluorescence photomicrograph of a renal biopsy specimen (very high magnification)

Subepithelial deposits of C3 are seen distributed within the capillary loops. The deposits are visible as bright green fluorescence in an irregular granular pattern.

This finding is typical of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.

H) INCORRECT:

Apple-green birefringence is seen on Congo red stained preparations in amyloidosis, which can manifest with nephrotic syndrome. Amyloidosis is often associated with multiple myeloma or other systemic illnesses (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn disease). Amyloidosis would be an uncommon cause of nephrotic syndrome in this child, especially without signs and symptoms of systemic illness (fever, arthralgia, myalgia).

I) INCORRECT:

Proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia are suggestive of nephrotic syndrome, with minimal change disease being the most likely cause in children. While minimal change disease is characterized by effacement of foot processes of the podocytes, this can only be seen on electron microscopy. Effacement of foot processes of podocytes is also seen in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, which can cause nephrotic syndrome, but is rare in children.
Image Description:

Electron micrograph of kidney tissue

The effacement of the podocytes foot processes is visible (examples indicated by green outline) as well as swelling of podocyte bodies (example indicated by red overlay).

This finding, together with unremarkable light microscopy, is typical of minimal change disease.

J) INCORRECT:

Segmental sclerosis on light microscopy is seen in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in African Americans and has also been associated with HIV, obesity, and sickle cell disease. While FSGS may also occur in children, it is not the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in pediatric patients.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (PAS stain; very high magnification)

A cross-section of a glomerulus is visible at the center of the image. The perihilar region is hypercellular and contains hyaline deposits (examples indicated by blue overlay). Loss of the capillary lumens and diffuse sclerosis is also present.

These are the typical features of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (perihilar type).
questions.hint: Large proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia are indicative of nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of swelling of his face and legs for 5 days. He immigrated to the United States from Korea with his family 10 years ago. He has been healthy except for an episode of sore throat 2 weeks ago. His younger sister has type 1 diabetes mellitus. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 145/87 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital edema and 3+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.9 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8100/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
78 mg/dL


 Albumin

2.4 g/dL


 Hepatitis B surface antigen

positive


 Hepatitis B surface antibody
negative


 Complement C4
decreased


Urine



 Blood
negative


 Protein

4+


 Glucose
negative


 Protein/creatinine ratio
8.1 (N ≤ 0.2)


Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following additional findings?

choices.text: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody level in serum

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Subepithelial deposits of IgG and complement along the glomerular basement membrane (spike and dome appearance) are the classic finding in membranous nephropathy. The deposits can be seen on immunofluorescence microscopy and electron microscopy. In secondary membranous nephropathy, subendothelial deposits are also commonly seen. While membranous nephropathy is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in white adults, it is rare in the pediatric population. However, there are certain factors that increase the risk of membranous nephropathy in children and adolescents as well, such as early hepatitis B infection, transmitted either vertically or horizontally.

While membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is also associated with hepatitis B, it is less common than membranous nephropathy and would show splitting of basement membrane on renal biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (Jones silver stain; very high magnification)

Thickening of the basement membrane (indicated by yellow outlines) with spike formation (examples indicated by blue arrowheads) can be seen.

This histopathologic appearance is characteristic of membranous nephropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules, glomerular basement membrane thickening, and mesangial expansion are the characteristic renal biopsy findings in diabetic nephropathy. Early in the course of the disease, this complication of diabetes mellitus typically manifests with asymptomatic microalbuminuria. In later stages, nephrotic syndrome, which is seen here, is the most common presentation. Since this patient has a family history of type 1 diabetes mellitus, he may have an increased risk of developing the condition. However, his normal serum glucose and the absence of glucosuria make the diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney autopsy specimen (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Nodular glomerulosclerosis in diabetic nephropathy (Kimmelstiel-Wilson syndrome) displays with mesangial thickening due to nodular, hyaline deposits (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions; yellow overlay) within the glomerulus (blue overlay). Further findings include thickening of the tubular basement membranes, tubular atrophy, and an increase of interstitial connective tissue between renal tubules (interstitial fibrosis).

Nodular glomerulosclerosis takes a decade or longer to develop in diabetes mellitus.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) INCORRECT:

Antistreptolysin O titers are used to assess for recent infections in patients presenting with complications of streptococcal infection, such as poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). PSGN typically develops 1–6 weeks following an acute infection, such as acute tonsillitis or tissue infections. However, the condition usually manifests with signs of nephritic rather than nephrotic syndrome. Moreover, affected children are usually between 3–12 years of age, making the diagnosis unlikely in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) levels are elevated in small-vessel vasculitides such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis, microscopic polyangiitis, and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, any of which may manifest with glomerulonephritis. However, nephritic syndrome is a more common manifestation than nephrotic syndrome, which is seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient does not have any other signs of systemic vasculitis, such as respiratory involvement (e.g., hemoptysis, asthma, or allergic rhinitis) or skin findings (e.g., purpura, tender nodules), making the diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with nephrotic syndrome, normal-appearing glomeruli on light microscopy without immunoglobulin or complement deposits suggest minimal change disease (MCD). While MCD is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, it is most often diagnosed in children younger than 6 years of age. Furthermore, complement levels are usually normal in MCD and, in contrast to other etiologies of nephrotic syndrome, hypertension is uncommon.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tissue obtained from renal biopsy (H&E stain; high magnification)

The basement membrane of the glomerulus is intact, the mesangium does not show proliferation. The capillary lumens are visible and there are no vascular changes.

This is the typical appearance of a glomerulus in minimal change disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Increased serum IgA levels are associated with IgA nephropathy, which is a possible cause of glomerulonephritis. It typically manifests in patients in their second to third decade of life and is more common in individuals of Asian descent. Chronic hepatitis B infection may occur in conjunction with IgA nephropathy, but this child has no evidence of chronic liver disease (e.g., ascites, jaundice). Moreover, IgA nephropathy typically causes nephritic syndrome rather than nephrotic syndrome. Most commonly, IgA nephropathy manifests with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria during mucosal infections (e.g., upper respiratory tract infection, gastrointestinal infection), or microscopic hematuria and mild proteinuria.
questions.hint: This boy has features of nephrotic syndrome, i.e., swelling of the face and extremities, hypoalbuminemia, and heavy proteinuria (4+ on urine dipstick), and serology that is positive for hepatitis B. Membranous nephropathy frequently occurs in association with hepatitis B, which is more common in some African and Asian countries (e.g., China and Korea).

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, lethargy, and swelling of the lower legs for 2 months. She reports recurrent episodes of pain in both wrists, her right knee, and her right ankle in the past year. She has had skin problems that are aggravated by exposure to sunlight for the past 18 months. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. She immigrated to the USA from France 8 months ago. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally and periorbital edema. There are erythematous patches with scaling on both cheeks. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8500/mm3



Platelet count
130,000/mm3



Serum



 Urea nitrogen
36 mg/dL


 Glucose
77 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


 Albumin

2.6 mg/dL


 Total cholesterol

295 mg/dL


 Triglycerides

215 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
negative


 Glucose
negative


 Protein

4+


 WBC
0–1/hpf


 Fatty casts
numerous


A renal biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Thickening of the capillary loops and glomerular basement membrane (GBM) under light microscopy indicates membranous nephropathy. This finding is secondary to subepithelial deposits of IgG and C3 between the GBM and podocytes, which have a spike and dome appearance under electron microscopy. These deposits result from immune complex accumulation which can manifest in individuals with SLE, such as this patient. Treatment consists of RAAS inhibitors, corticosteroids, and supportive management of nephrotic syndrome (e.g., dietary sodium restriction, fluid restriction, diuretic therapy).

Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) is another common variant of lupus nephritis, which can also result in thickening of the capillaries. Additionally, a biopsy typically shows increased glomerular cellularity in more than half of the glomeruli and subendothelial immune deposits. DPGN most commonly manifests with nephritic syndrome or nephritic-nephrotic syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy sample (PAS stain; 550× magnification)

There is diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (blue overlay) and capillaries.

These are typical microscopic findings of membranous glomerulopathy (most common glomerulonephritis in adults).

B) INCORRECT:

Nodular glomerulosclerosis (i.e., Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules) is seen on light microscopy in patients with diabetic nephropathy following mesangial expansion and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, which is caused by chronic hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, elevated growth hormones, and intraglomerular hypertension. Although later stages of the condition can cause nephrotic syndrome, nodular glomerulosclerosis is not associated with SLE. Moreover, this patient has normal serum glucose, no glucosuria on urinalysis, and no history of diabetes mellitus.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain; high magnification)

A cross-section of a glomerulus can be seen (dashed outline), featuring a thickened glomerular basement membrane and containing abundant pink, hyaline depositions of PAS-positive material (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules or nodular glomerulosclerosis; examples indicated by yellow overlay). Various tubules and vessels surround the glomerulus. An arteriole with distinct hyaline deposits is located above the glomerulus (hyaline arteriolosclerosis; blue overlay).

Nodular glomerulosclerosis combined with hyaline arteriolosclerosis is a typical feature seen in diabetic glomerulopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Segmental sclerosis on light microscopy is seen in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in African Americans and is also associated with HIV, obesity, and sickle cell disease. While this patient's presentation is consistent with FSGS, she has no risk factors for this condition. A white patient with SLE is more likely to have membranous nephropathy, which is not associated with segmental sclerosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (PAS stain; very high magnification)

A cross-section of a glomerulus is visible at the center of the image. The perihilar region is hypercellular and contains hyaline deposits (examples indicated by blue overlay). Loss of the capillary lumens and diffuse sclerosis is also present.

These are the typical features of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (perihilar type).

D) INCORRECT:

Crescent formation in the glomeruli, which can be seen on light microscopy, is characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Breaks in the glomerular capillary wall (due to any kind of severe injury) lead to an accumulation of plasma products (e.g., fibrinogen) within the Bowman's capsule and result in fibrin formation that causes the crescent appearance. RPGN manifests with gross hematuria, elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., leukocytosis), and nephritic sediment on urinalysis. Renal insufficiency is usually pronounced at diagnosis, with a marked increase in creatinine (often > 3 mg/dL), decreased urine output, hypertension, and edema.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy sample (PAS stain; very high magnification)

The glomerulus shows a hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone (green overlay) with an inflammatory infiltrate (examples of macrophages indicated by arrowheads).

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

E) INCORRECT:

Apple-green birefringence is seen on Congo-red-stained preparations in amyloidosis. Reactive amyloidosis most commonly involves the kidneys, causing nephrotic syndrome, but, since it is a systemic condition, involvement of the liver, spleen, and gastrointestinal tract would also be expected. More importantly, it is associated with longstanding inflammatory conditions (primarily rheumatoid arthritis and chronic inflammatory bowel disease). Although it can also occur in patients with SLE, which this patient likely has, amyloidosis secondary to SLE is rare and unlikely in this patient, considering her short history of SLE.
Image Description:

Polarized light photomicrograph of the kidney (Congo red stain; 300x magnification)

The sediments in the area of the glomeruli and renal interstitium (white arrow; white arrowheads) appear birefringent in the polarized light and bright green in color (characteristic of amyloids).

These are both key diagnostic features of amyloid sediments.

F) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane (tram-track appearance) on electron microscopy is seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. Although this condition is associated with SLE, which this patient likely has, active disease usually manifests with microscopic hematuria, with a varying degree of proteinuria and elevated creatinine.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (PAS stain; high magnification)

The glomerulus shows slightly increased mesangial cellularity (examples indicated by circles) and duplication of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). The latter displays in the form of a double contour of the GBM (tram-track appearance; examples indicated by yellow lines).
As a secondary finding, there is an Angiostrongylus larva within the glomerulus (blue overlay).

Duplication of the GBM is a typical finding in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.
questions.hint: Edema, massive proteinuria, fatty casts, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia are suggestive of nephrotic syndrome, which is most commonly caused by membranous nephropathy in adults of European, Middle Eastern, or North African descent. Recurrent arthralgia, fatigue, photosensitivity, and a discoid rash suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) as an underlying cause.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old white man comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of fatigue and lower leg swelling. Over the past 6 months, he has had a 3.6-kg (8-lb) weight loss. He has chronic bronchitis and uses an albuterol inhaler as needed. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 44 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. He appears thin. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8500/mm3



Platelet count
130,000/mm3



Serum



 Urea nitrogen
23 mg/dL


 Glucose
77 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.6 mg/dL


 Albumin

1.8 mg/dL


 Total cholesterol

475 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
negative


 Glucose
negative


 Protein

4+


 WBC
0–1/hpf


 Fatty casts

numerous


An x-ray of the chest shows a right upper lobe density. A CT scan of the chest shows a 2.5 x 3.5 x 2-cm right upper lobe mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in Black adults. It can arise in association with heroin abuse, HIV infection, obesity, and sickle cell disease. This patient does not have any of these risk factors, making FSGS an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is characterized by gross hematuria and flank pain that is preceded by upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infections. Urinalysis would show hematuria and minor proteinuria, and more severe cases can manifest with recurrent episodes of nephritic syndrome. Features of pulmonary pathology (e.g., cough, dyspnea, crackles, infiltrates on chest x-ray) may also present concurrently because respiratory infections such as pneumonia can be triggers for IgA nephropathy. However, this patient has no pulmonary symptoms or signs of systemic infection (e.g., fever, leukocytosis).

C) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis can arise in association with systemic lupus erythematosus, hepatitis C, monoclonal gammopathy, or may be due to overactivation of the alternative complement pathway. Active disease usually manifests with microscopic hematuria with a varying degree of proteinuria and elevated creatinine. In this patient, features of nephrotic syndrome rather than nephritic syndrome predominate, making this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis manifests with constitutional symptoms (fatigue, weight loss, fever, arthralgia) accompanied by pulmonary and nasopharyngeal involvement (e.g., chronic sinusitis, rhinitis, otitis media) and/or skin lesions, which this patient does not have. In later stages, more serious manifestations may arise, including pulmonary complications and glomerulonephritis that is characterized by nephritic syndrome. In this patient, features of nephrotic syndrome rather than nephritic syndrome predominate.

E) CORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in white adults. Although the majority of cases are idiopathic, the condition can arise in association with solid malignancies, such as lung cancer, particularly in patients aged > 65 years, as well as in association with infections (e.g., hepatitis B virus, malaria), autoimmune disease (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus), or medications (e.g., NSAIDs). Deposition of antibodies between podocytes and the basal membrane causes thickening of glomerular capillary loops and basal membrane, which in turn leads to nephrotic syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy sample (PAS stain; 550× magnification)

There is diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (blue overlay) and capillaries.

These are typical microscopic findings of membranous glomerulopathy (most common glomerulonephritis in adults).

F) INCORRECT:

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis can occur in association with numerous glomerulonephritides and is characterized by gross hematuria, elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., leukocytosis), rapid increases in blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine, and nephritic sediment on urinalysis. Decreased urine output, hypertension, and edema are signs of progression to renal failure, which can occur quickly; diagnosis and initiation of immunosuppressive therapy should therefore not be delayed. In this patient, features of nephrotic syndrome predominate, however.

G) INCORRECT:

Thin basement membrane disease is characterized by episodes of intermittent gross hematuria and flank pain that are often triggered by upper respiratory tract infections or exercise. Urinalysis shows persistent microhematuria and sometimes proteinuria, which is not consistent with this patient's findings.
questions.hint: This patient presents with proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia, the defining features of nephrotic syndrome. Additionally, the right upper lobe mass combined with his recent weight loss and smoking history are highly suggestive of lung cancer.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive swelling of his legs over the past 2 months. During this period, the patient has had an unintentional 5-kg (11-lb) weight gain. He also reports frequent numbness of the tips of his fingers and cramping in his back and leg muscles. He has a history of HIV infection treated with combined antiretroviral therapy. The patient immigrated to the US from Nigeria 3 years ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 3+ periorbital and lower extremity edema bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased around the mouth and along the fingers. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Albumin

2.5 g/dL


 Total cholesterol

270 mg/dL


 HIV antibody
positive


Urine



 Blood
negative


 Protein

+4


 RBC
1-2/hpf


 RBC casts
negative


A kidney biopsy is most likely to show which of the following findings under light microscopy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thickened glomerular capillary loops are typical biopsy findings in patients with membranous nephropathy, which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in white populations. Although membranous nephropathy may also occur in patients with HIV infection, it has stronger correlation with hepatitis B and hepatitis C, as well as systemic lupus erythematosus and solid tumors, making another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy sample (PAS stain; 550× magnification)

There is diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (blue overlay) and capillaries.

These are typical microscopic findings of membranous glomerulopathy (most common glomerulonephritis in adults).

B) INCORRECT:

Nodules within glomeruli (so-called Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules) and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane are typically caused by diabetic nephropathy. Although later stages of the disease manifest with nephrotic syndrome, this patient has no history of diabetes mellitus and no glucosuria on urinalysis, making another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney autopsy specimen (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Nodular glomerulosclerosis in diabetic nephropathy (Kimmelstiel-Wilson syndrome) displays with mesangial thickening due to nodular, hyaline deposits (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions; yellow overlay) within the glomerulus (blue overlay). Further findings include thickening of the tubular basement membranes, tubular atrophy, and an increase of interstitial connective tissue between renal tubules (interstitial fibrosis).

Nodular glomerulosclerosis takes a decade or longer to develop in diabetes mellitus.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with several typical features of nephrotic syndrome, most likely due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which commonly appears as segmental sclerosis under light microscopy. FSGS is associated with heroin abuse, obesity, sickle cell disease, and HIV infection (HIV-associated nephropathy). Without immunosuppressive treatment, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis usually leads to end stage renal disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (PAS stain; very high magnification)

A cross-section of a glomerulus is visible at the center of the image. The perihilar region is hypercellular and contains hyaline deposits (examples indicated by blue overlay). Loss of the capillary lumens and diffuse sclerosis is also present.

These are the typical features of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (perihilar type).

D) INCORRECT:

A crescent-shaped formation, monocytes, and macrophages are common findings in kidney biopsies of patients with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Although RPGN may also cause hypertension and edema, it would typically manifest with gross hematuria, elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., leukocytosis), and nephritic sediment on urinalysis. Renal insufficiency is usually pronounced at diagnosis, with a marked increase in creatinine (often > 3 mg/dL) and decreased urine output, making the diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy sample (PAS stain; very high magnification)

The glomerulus shows a hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone (green overlay) with an inflammatory infiltrate (examples of macrophages indicated by arrowheads).

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

E) INCORRECT:

Mesangial proliferation is a characteristic finding of IgA nephropathy (Berger disease). IgA nephropathy is the most common type of primary glomerulonephritis and typically leads to nephritic rather than nephrotic syndrome. IgA nephropathy is usually triggered by upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infections and typically manifests with gross hematuria and flank pain, none of which are present in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

F) INCORRECT:

Kidney biopsies of patients with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis often show enlarged and hypercellular glomeruli under light microscopy. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis commonly occurs ∼ 1–6 weeks following acute infection with group A β-hemolytic streptococci. The condition is a frequent cause of nephritic rather than nephrotic syndrome and mostly affects children, making another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of a kidney biopsy (PAS stain, high magnification)

A renal corpuscle surrounded by numerous tubules can be seen in the center of the image. Because the renal corpuscle is markedly enlarged, the space between the glomerular capillaries and the parietal layer of the Bowman capsule (black dashed outline) is narrowed. Within the glomerulus, there is hypercellularity due to proliferation of endothelial cells (yellow arrowheads) and mesangial cells (black arrowheads). Inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly neutrophils (blue arrowheads) and monocytes (white arrowheads), is also present. As a result, the lumina of the capillaries are not clearly identifiable.

This is the histopathologic appearance of postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

G) INCORRECT:

An absence of changes under light microscopy is a common finding in patients with minimal change disease, which typically causes nephrotic syndrome. However, it most commonly presents in children < 6 years of age with an acute onset of symptoms within days or 1–2 weeks following a viral infection such as viral pharyngitis. This patient's symptoms developed more gradually over a 2-month period and are associated with HIV infection, making another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tissue obtained from renal biopsy (H&E stain; high magnification)

The basement membrane of the glomerulus is intact, the mesangium does not show proliferation. The capillary lumens are visible and there are no vascular changes.

This is the typical appearance of a glomerulus in minimal change disease.
questions.hint: This patient has several features of nephrotic syndrome, i.e., edema of the face and extremities, hypoalbuminemia, hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, weight gain, symptoms of hypocalcemia (paresthesias, muscle cramping), and heavy proteinuria (4+ on urine dipstick). The most likely diagnosis is a condition that is more common among patients with HIV infection and also the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in black populations.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of right flank pain and bloody urine. Over the past 2 weeks, she has also developed progressive lower extremity swelling and a 3-kg (7-lb) weight gain. She has a history of chronic hepatitis B infection, which was diagnosed 10 years ago. She frequently flies from California to New York for business. She appears fatigued. Her pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital edema, a distended abdomen, and 2+ edema of the lower extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a nodular liver with ascites, a large right kidney with abundant collateral vessels, and a filling defect in the right renal vein. Urinalysis shows 4+ protein, positive glucose, and fatty casts. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's renal vein findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of coagulation factors, such as factor VIII, typically leads to bleeding, not hypercoagulability. Furthermore, nephrotic syndrome leads to an increase, not decrease, in the serum concentrations of many coagulation factors, including factor VIII, factor X, and fibrinogen.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with chronic hepatitis B infection are at increased risk of developing membranous nephropathy, which leads to HBV-associated nephrotic syndrome. Urinary loss of proteins, such as antithrombin III, can lead to a hypercoagulable state and subsequent formation of venous and arterial thrombosis. Renal vein thromboses secondary to nephrotic syndrome are often asymptomatic and identified incidentally (e.g., during evaluation of a pulmonary embolism). However, sudden development of flank pain and gross hematuria, as seen in this patient, can be caused by an acute, complete renal vein thrombosis.

Additional loss of protein (mainly albumin) reduces intravascular oncotic pressure, leading to fluid shifting into the extravascular space (e.g., lower extremity edema, ascites). In addition, the loss of albumin leads to elevated lipoprotein levels that cause hyperlipidemia and fatty casts, which are characteristic of nephrotic syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Prolonged immobility leads to venous stasis and is a risk factor for venous thromboembolism. The greatest risk is seen in individuals who have been immobile for over 48 hours in the preceding month (e.g., due to hospitalization or recent surgery). This patient has no history of immobility. Prolonged travel for more than 12 hours can contribute to a mildly increased risk of venous thromboembolism. However, the shorter domestic flights that this patient has been taking are unlikely to cause thrombosis of the renal vein.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired estrogen degradation can be caused by progressive cirrhosis, which results in decreased cytochrome P450 enzymatic activity in the liver. Increased estrogen concentrations, in turn, result in an increase in the concentrations of clotting factors II, VII, VIII, X, XII, and fibrinogen, which leads to a hypercoagulable state. Although this patient has evidence of liver disease on CT scan, most likely caused by chronic hepatitis B infection, other manifestations of a high-estrogen state (e.g., spider angiomata) are absent.

E) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid antibodies, which can develop in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune diseases, can induce a hypercoagulable state by inhibiting coagulation factors and activating platelets. Patients with SLE can also develop nephrotic syndrome. Though this patient has a hypercoagulable state and nephrotic syndrome, she has no history or clinical features that suggest autoimmune disease as an underlying cause of renal vein thrombosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic production of erythropoietin (EPO) can develop in patients with renal cell carcinoma and hepatocellular carcinoma. Increased EPO causes a hypercoagulable state via secondary polycythemia, which can result in thrombosis. Although renal cell carcinoma can also manifest with hematuria and flank pain, and this patient's history of chronic hepatitis B infection increases her risk for developing hepatocellular carcinoma, the abdominal CT scan shows no evidence of a renal or hepatic tumor.
questions.hint: The urinalysis findings (significant proteinuria, glucosuria, fatty casts), along with lower extremity edema and weight gain, strongly suggest a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome. This patient's flank pain and hematuria with an identified filling defect indicate an acute renal vein thrombosis, which is likely to have been caused by the hypercoagulable state induced by nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and swelling of his legs and feet for 6 weeks. During this time, he has felt like his eyes have been unusually puffy in the mornings and his urine has been frothy. He has hypertension and rheumatoid factor-positive rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include amlodipine, methotrexate, and ibuprofen. He does not smoke. He has a history of chronic alcohol use. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor, periorbital edema, 2+ pedal edema, and ascites. He has swan-neck deformities and nodules on multiple fingers and swelling and restricted range of motion of bilateral knee joints. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
8.2 mg/dL


Prothrombin time
12 sec


Serum



 Albumin
2.8 g/dL


 Total bilirubin
1.0 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
80 U/L


 AST
20 U/L


 ALT
19 U/L


 Urea
18 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL


Urine



 Protein

3+


 WBCs
5–10/hpf


 RBCs
negative


 Bacteria
negative


Ultrasound of the liver and kidneys shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased hepatic albumin production suggests liver failure, which is often caused by chronic alcohol use and can manifest with edema, ascites, and hypoalbuminemia. This patient's liver function tests, however, are all within normal limits and ultrasound shows no hepatic abnormalities. In patients with nephrotic syndrome, hypoalbuminemia is caused by renal protein loss, which typically leads to a compensatory increase (rather than decrease) in hepatic albumin production.

B) INCORRECT:

One common adverse effect of amlodipine and other calcium channel blockers is pedal edema, which is present in this patient. However, amlodipine use does not explain this patient's periorbital edema, ascites, or proteinuria.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal deposition of AL amyloid suggests AL amyloidosis affecting the kidneys, which can also cause nephrotic syndrome. However, patients with AL amyloidosis typically have a plasma cell dyscrasia, such as multiple myeloma, which is not seen here.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic inflammatory processes such as rheumatoid arthritis can increase the production of serum amyloid A (SAA), an acute phase reactant. Reactive amyloidosis (AA amyloidosis) leads to the deposition of SAA in the kidneys, which commonly manifests with nephrotic syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal deposition of anti-dsDNA immune complex suggests lupus nephritis, which classically manifests with proteinuria, hematuria, and casts on urine microscopy, including red blood cell, hemoglobin, granular, tubular, or mixed casts. Although this patient does have proteinuria, he does not have other classic findings that suggest underlying systemic lupus erythematosus.
questions.hint: This patient's history of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis has played an important role in the development of nephrotic syndrome (pedal and periorbital edema, proteinuria). The frothy urine is likely secondary to proteinuria and the anemia is most likely due to chronic methotrexate use and/or anemia of chronic disease.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of gradually worsening facial and lower extremity swelling. She has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight gain during this time. Her blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital edema and 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. A 24-hour collection of urine shows 4.0 g of proteinuria. Microscopic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen shows thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. Electron microscopy shows dense subepithelial deposits. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibodies are found in primary membranous nephropathy. Deposition of antibodies between podocytes and the glomerular basal membrane (GBM) causes thickening of glomerular capillary loops and the GBM, which in turn leads to nephrotic syndrome. On electron microscopy, the subepithelial immune deposits are reflected in a “spike and dome” appearance.

Secondary membranous nephropathy can be caused by infection (e.g., HBV, HCV) or systemic lupus erythematosus.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy sample (PAS stain; 550× magnification)

There is diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (blue overlay) and capillaries.

These are typical microscopic findings of membranous glomerulopathy (most common glomerulonephritis in adults).

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies (p-ANCA) are found in microscopic polyangiitis and Churg-Strauss syndrome. These vasculitides are most commonly associated with RPGN, which appears on light microscopy as “crescent moon-shaped” extracapillary cell proliferation that displaces the glomerulus, in contrast to the thickened appearance of the glomerular basement membrane described in this patient. Furthermore, RPGN causes nephritic syndrome, defined by proteinuria < 3.5 g/24 h, whereas this patient has nephrotic syndrome. Lastly, this patient lacks symptoms of p-ANCA-associated vasculitis such as palpable purpura.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-streptolysin O antibodies are indicative of infection with group A Streptococcus, which can result in PSGN. Although PSGN does take the form of subepithelial immune complex deposits ("lumpy-bumpy" appearance) on immunofluorescence microscopy, it does not usually involve glomerular basement membrane thickening. Moreover, glomeruli in PSGN would appear hypercellular due to infiltration of monocytes and polymorphonuclear cells. Lastly, PSGN causes nephritic syndrome, defined by proteinuria < 3.5 g/24 h, whereas this patient has nephrotic syndrome.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of a kidney biopsy (PAS stain, high magnification)

A renal corpuscle surrounded by numerous tubules can be seen in the center of the image. Because the renal corpuscle is markedly enlarged, the space between the glomerular capillaries and the parietal layer of the Bowman capsule (black dashed outline) is narrowed. Within the glomerulus, there is hypercellularity due to proliferation of endothelial cells (yellow arrowheads) and mesangial cells (black arrowheads). Inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly neutrophils (blue arrowheads) and monocytes (white arrowheads), is also present. As a result, the lumina of the capillaries are not clearly identifiable.

This is the histopathologic appearance of postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-proteinase 3 antibodies (c-ANCA) are seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis can manifest with RPGN, which appears on light microscopy as “crescent moon-shaped” extracapillary cell proliferation that displaces the glomerulus, in contrast to the thickened appearance of the glomerular basement membrane described in this patient. Furthermore, RPGN causes nephritic syndrome, defined by proteinuria < 3.5 g/24 h, whereas this patient has nephrotic syndrome. Lastly, this patient lacks features of this condition such as skin lesions and chronic sinusitis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-C3 convertase antibodies can be found in complement-mediated membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). These antibodies activate the complement system and lead to complement deposition within the glomerulus. MPGN can also present with nephrotic syndrome. However, the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) in MPGN appears split on light microscopy, with a characteristic “train-track” appearance, in contrast to the thickened appearance of the GBM described in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Anti-type IV collagen antibodies (anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies) are seen in Goodpasture syndrome, which classically manifests as RPGN. RPGN appears on light microscopy as “crescent moon-shaped” extracapillary cell proliferation that displaces the glomerulus, in contrast to the thickened appearance of the glomerular basement membrane described in this patient. Furthermore, RPGN causes nephritic syndrome, defined by proteinuria < 3.5 g/24 h, whereas this patient has nephrotic syndrome. Lastly, this patient lacks symptoms of pulmonary involvement such as hemoptysis and cough.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.
questions.hint: Heavy proteinuria (> 3.5 g/24 h) on a 24-hour urine collection is the confirmatory test for the diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome, which classically presents with generalized edema and weight gain. A thickened glomerular basement membrane on light microscopy of the kidney biopsy specimen is consistent with membranous nephropathy, a common cause of nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue and weakness. Her hemoglobin A1c concentration was 13.5% 12 weeks ago. Her blood pressure is 152/92 mm Hg. Examination shows lower extremity edema. Serum studies show:


K+

5.1 mEq/L


Phosphorus
5.0 mg/dL


Ca2+

7.8 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
60 mg/dL


Creatinine
2.2 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most appropriate parameter for early detection of this patient’s renal condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of urinary red blood cell casts indicates glomerulonephritis (GN). This finding is caused by the congregation of proteins and RBCs inside the tubules. Clinically, GN can result in red or cola-colored urine, mild edema (due to the relatively limited loss of albumin), and hypertension (i.e., nephritic syndrome). However, diabetic nephropathy classically leads to nephrotic syndrome, not nephritic syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Diabetic nephropathy leads to nephrotic syndrome, which typically manifests with hypoproteinemia. However, total protein is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only decreases once there is significant glomerular damage.

C) CORRECT:

Microalbuminuria is the earliest diagnostic sign of diabetic nephropathy. Progression of glomerular damage (nodular glomerulosclerosis) leads to increased urinary loss of albumin, which can manifest as nephrotic syndrome. The extent of albuminuria in patients with diabetic nephropathy also correlates with the risk of future cardiovascular events. ACE inhibitors can prevent the progression of albuminuria in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum urea nitrogen (BUN) is routinely measured as part of renal function testing in patients with diabetic nephropathy and other forms of chronic kidney disease. However, BUN is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only rises once the glomerular filtration rate significantly deteriorates.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine is routinely measured as part of renal function testing in patients with diabetic nephropathy and other forms of chronic kidney disease. However, it is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only rises once the glomerular filtration rate significantly deteriorates.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents with features of diabetic nephropathy (elevated creatinine and BUN levels, arterial hypertension, electrolyte abnormalities, edema).

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden right flank pain that began 3 hours ago. He also noticed blood in his urine. Over the past two weeks, he has developed progressive lower extremity swelling and a 4-kg (9-lb) weight gain. Examination shows bilateral 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Urinalysis with dipstick shows 4+ protein, positive glucose, and multiple red cell and fatty casts. Abdominal CT shows a large right kidney with abundant collateral vessels and a filling defect in the right renal vein. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Factor V Leiden mutation, producing a Factor V that is resistant to degradation by protein C, is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulability in the Caucasian population. While this mutation does increase the risk of venous thromboembolism, it usually manifests as a DVT or PE. Furthermore, this patient's renal vein thrombosis occurring in the context of nephrotic syndrome makes another answer option more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

The significant loss of circulating protein in nephrotic syndrome induces a compensatory increase in the synthesis of lipoproteins to attempt to maintain oncotic pressure. This elevates circulating cholesterol and triglyceride levels, eventually leading to lipiduria, which manifests as fatty casts on urinalysis, as seen in this patient. However, this process does not induce hypercoagulability.

C) CORRECT:

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by a massive renal loss of protein due to structural damage of the glomerular filtration barrier. This nonselective proteinuria includes the loss of antithrombin III, leading to a hypercoagulable state due to decreased inhibition of Factor IIa and Factor Xa. The additional loss of albumin reduces the oncotic pressure inside blood vessels, leading to fluid shifts into the extravascular space, as evidenced by this patient's signs of volume overload (weight gain, lower extremity edema). Reduced intravascular volume significantly increases the risk of hypercoagulability and subsequent thromboembolic events, such as this patient's renal vein thrombosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased production of EPO can be a result of renal cell carcinoma. Increased EPO causes a hypercoagulable state via secondary polycythemia, which increases the risk of thrombosis. Although RCC can also present with hematuria and flank pain and even extend into the renal vein, the abdominal CT shows no evidence of tumor invasion in the renal capsule. RCC would also not account for this patient's nephrotic syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid antibodies can be seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE can also present with renal disease (lupus nephritis) and a hypercoagulable state, as these antibodies inhibit fibrinolysis and activate platelets and other procoagulant factors. However, a diagnosis of SLE is unlikely in a middle-aged man with no rash or history of autoimmune disease.
questions.hint: This patient's urinalysis (significant proteinuria, glycosuria, fatty casts) in the setting of lower extremity swelling and weight gain are highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. His flank pain and hematuria with an identified filling defect indicate an acute renal vein thrombosis, likely a result of a hypercoagulable state induced by nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old white man comes to the physician because of a 15-day history of fatigue and lower leg swelling. Over the past 8 months, he has had a 3.8-kg (8.3-lb) weight loss. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. He appears thin. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. An x-ray of the chest shows a right upper lobe density. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.3 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8600/mm3



Platelet count
140,000/mm3



Serum



 Urea nitrogen
25 mg/dL


 Glucose (fasting)
79 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.7 mg/dL


 Albumin
1.6 g/dL


 Total cholesterol
479 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
negative


 Glucose
negative


 Protein
4+


 WBC
0–1/hpf


 Fatty casts
numerous


Light microscopic examination of a kidney biopsy shows thickening of glomerular capillary loops and the basal membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

GPA manifests with constitutional symptoms (fatigue, weight loss, fever, arthralgia) accompanied by pulmonary and nasopharyngeal involvement (e.g., chronic sinusitis, rhinitis, otitis media) and/or skin lesions, which this patient does not have. In later stages, more serious manifestations may arise, including pulmonary complications and glomerulonephritis that is characterized by nephritic syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

MPGN can arise in association with SLE, hepatitis C, or MGUS, or may be due to overactivation of the alternative complement pathway. Active disease usually presents with microscopic hematuria with a varying degree of proteinuria and elevated creatinine. Unlike this patient, biopsy results in MPGN would show thickening and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane ("train-track" appearance).

C) INCORRECT:

FSGN is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in Black adults. It can arise in association with heroin abuse, HIV infection, obesity, and sickle cell disease. This patient does not have any of these risk factors, making FSGS an unlikely diagnosis. In addition, biopsy results in FSGN would show segmental sclerosis and loss of podocytes.

D) INCORRECT:

RPGN can occur in association with numerous glomerulonephritides and is characterized by macroscopic hematuria, elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., leukocytosis), rapid increases in BUN and serum creatinine, and nephritic sediment on urinalysis (not present in this patient). Biopsy results in RPGN would show a crescent-moon-shaped extracapillary cell proliferation that displaces the glomerulus.

E) CORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in White adults. Although the majority of cases are idiopathic, the condition can arise in association with solid malignancies, such as lung cancer, particularly in patients > 65 years. Deposition of antibodies between podocytes and the basal membrane causes thickening of glomerular capillary loops and the basal membrane, which in turn leads to nephrotic syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (Jones silver stain; very high magnification)

Thickening of the basement membrane (indicated by yellow outlines) with spike formation (examples indicated by blue arrowheads) can be seen.

This histopathologic appearance is characteristic of membranous nephropathy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia – the defining features of nephrotic syndrome. Additionally, the radiographic findings combined with his recent weight loss and history of smoking are highly suggestive of lung cancer.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of lower extremity swelling and frothy urine. He has a history of chronic hepatitis C infection. Physical examination shows 3+ pitting edema of the lower legs and ankles. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased blood urea nitrogen can be seen in malnutrition due to decreased protein intake; urea is a nitrogenous breakdown product of proteins. In nephrotic syndrome, BUN would most likely be normal (or slightly elevated) due to hemoconcentration secondary to third-spacing of fluid. Elevated BUN levels would indicate progression of renal impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

Structural damage to the glomerular filtration barrier in nephrotic syndrome can result in loss of cholesterol and triglycerides in the urine (i.e., lipiduria). However, the loss of protein caused by nephrotic syndrome causes the liver to increase cholesterol production in an attempt to maintain the oncotic pressure. This results in increased rather than decreased serum cholesterol levels.

C) CORRECT:

Hypoalbuminemia due to loss of protein in the urine leads to reduced oncotic pressure, which results in a shift of water into the interstitium and subsequent edema formation. Decreased renal blood flow activates the RAAS to increase renal water and salt reabsorption, thereby worsening the edema. To maintain the oncotic pressure, an increase in hepatic lipoprotein synthesis occurs. Increased glomerular permeability results in lipiduria and fatty casts in the urine.

Proteinuria also leads to loss of antithrombin III (resulting in hypercoagulability), antibodies (increased risk of infection), and various transport proteins (risk of vitamin D deficiency, thyroxine deficiency, and altered pharmacodynamics of drugs).

D) INCORRECT:

Cystatin C levels, which are used to assess kidney function, would be normal rather than decreased in nephrotic syndrome. In the event that this patient develops acute kidney injury (e.g., due to hypovolemia from severe third-spacing of fluid), increased cystatin C levels would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Structural damage to the glomerular filtration barrier in nephrotic syndrome results in increased renal excretion of antithrombin III. Therefore, antithrombin III would be decreased rather than increased in this patient. Decreased antithrombin III levels, a deficiency in other anticoagulant proteins (e.g., protein C, protein S), increased production of fibrinogen, as well as hemoconcentration from third-spacing of fluid result in a hypercoagulable state.

F) INCORRECT:

An increase in serum immunoglobulin levels is classically seen in viral and bacterial infections. Because immunoglobulins are excreted renally, structural damage to the glomerular filtration barrier (as seen in nephrotic syndrome) would result in a loss of immunoglobulins. Therefore, decreased levels of circulating immunoglobulins with an increased risk of infection would be expected in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient with pitting edema and frothy urine (which indicates proteinuria) most likely has nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by structural damage to the glomerular filtration barrier resulting in a loss of protein. Hepatitis C infection is associated with membranous nephropathy, which typically presents with nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of progressively worsening swelling around the eyes. He has no history of major medical illness. He had a sore throat and cough 2 weeks ago that resolved spontaneously. Physical examination shows moderate periorbital edema and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. A kidney biopsy specimen shows effacement of the podocytes on electron microscopy. Which of the following is most likely to be found on urinalysis?

choices.text: Red blood cell casts and acanthocytes
White blood cell casts and eosinophils
Granular casts and tubular epithelial cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyaline casts can be found in a variety of renal conditions, even in healthy patients after exercise. Urinalysis showing immunoglobulins indicates a form of nephrotic syndrome that involves nonselective glomerular proteinuria, the most common of which being membranous nephropathy. Membranous nephropathy is characterized by a diffuse thickening of the GBM secondary to fusion of the foot processes of podocytes, which allows various proteins to pass through into the urine, including high molecular weight proteins such as IGs. On electron microscopy, the hallmark finding is subepithelial dense deposits, giving a characteristic “spike and dome” appearance, which is not present in this patient. Additionally, although membranous nephropathy is the most common nephrotic syndrome in adults, it is rarely seen in children.

B) INCORRECT:

RBC casts and acanthocytes in urinalysis are consistent with nephritic syndrome, which in children, is often caused by poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). This patient presents with signs of PSGN, including edema and a history of sore throat two weeks before that could have been due to nephritogenic strains of group A (beta-hemolytic) Streptococcus pyogenes. However, PSGN would show a “lumpy-bumpy” appearance on electron microscopy that is caused by the deposition of immune complexes containing the streptococcal antigen into the GBM. Additionally, this patient does not present with hematuria, as would be expected in nephritic syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Fatty casts and albumin are the expected findings in MCD, in which structural damage to the podocytes and loss of the GBM negative charge results in a loss of protein (specifically, anionic albumin) into the urine. To compensate for the renal loss of albumin, the liver increases lipoprotein synthesis. Lipids are then seen in the urine as fatty casts because of the increased glomerular permeability.

D) INCORRECT:

WBC casts and eosinophils are seen in acute interstitial nephritis, which is most often induced by a drug reaction. Among the most common culprits are beta-lactam antibiotics and NSAIDs. These agents act as haptens that trigger a hypersensitivity reaction, typically resulting in painless hematuria and pyuria. WBCs and eosinophils show up on urinalysis, indicating generalized inflammation in the kidney; however, eosinophiluria may be found in other renal conditions as well. Classically, patients with drug-induced AIN present with symptoms of an allergic response, including rash and fever. This patient has no known recent drug exposure or allergic symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Granular casts and tubular epithelial cells are expected urinalysis findings in acute tubular necrosis (ATN), in which tubular epithelial cell injury occurs typically due to renal ischemia (hypotension, surgery, shock) or nephrotoxicity (medications, contrast, free myoglobin). The necrotic cells then slough off and occlude the tubular lumen, causing muddy brown, granular casts and free renal tubular epithelial cells to appear in urinalysis. Although ATN can present with edema, patients would generally have a history of hypotension, fluid depletion, or exposure to nephrotoxins, unlike in this boy.
questions.hint: This patient's biopsy finding of effacement of the podocytes indicates minimal change disease (MCD), the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. A presentation of periorbital and lower extremity edema a couple weeks after a potential viral infection (i.e., sore throat) is consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of increasing swelling around her eyes and over both her feet for the past 4 days. During this period, she has had frothy light yellow urine. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows periorbital edema and 2+ pitting edema of the lower legs and ankles. A urinalysis of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Muddy brown casts are a type of granular cast most often associated with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) that originate from the fusion of plasma proteins shed from damaged epithelial cells of the tubule lining. This patient's history is not consistent with any conditions that predispose to ATN (e.g., prolonged hypotension/renal infarction, toxin ingestion, or adverse effect of nephrotoxic drugs), making this finding much less likely. ATN would also not explain her nephrotic syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Epithelial casts in the urine sediment are the result of a process that causes necrosis of the renal tubule epithelium. Consequently, the epithelial cells slough off into the lumen and appear as casts. Possible etiologies include acute tubular necrosis (e.g., due to prolonged hypotension/renal infarction or administration of a nephrotoxic drug), toxic ingestion, or infection with cytomegalovirus. This patient's history does not support any of these causes, making this answer unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Fatty casts are very common in the urinary sediment of patients with nephrotic syndrome. Massive proteinuria (> 3.5 g/24 h) results in low serum albumin, leading to reduced capillary oncotic pressure, thereby causing edema secondary to fluid leaking into tissue. Consequently, the liver increases all synthetic activity (involving albumin as well as other macromolecules, such as lipids) to compensate. Some of these excess lipids are reabsorbed by the proximal tubular epithelial cells. Once the cytoplasm becomes engorged, chunks of the cell can slough off into the tubular lumen, leading to the classic fatty casts on urinary sediment.

Patients with nephrotic syndrome are at high risk of developing infections (due to urinary loss of IgG), hypocalcemia (due to vitamin D deficiency), and venous thrombus formation (due to urinary loss of antithrombin III and loss of fluid into the extravascular space).

D) INCORRECT:

Red blood cells in urinary sediment are always abnormal. Their presence indicates glomerulonephritis (GN) and is caused by the congregation of proteins and RBCs inside the tubules. Clinically, GN results in red or cola-colored urine with much milder edema due to the relatively limited loss of albumin (< 3.5 g/24 h). This patient has yellow urine and likely nephrotic syndrome (as indicated by the periorbital edema, pedal edema, and frothy urine), so RBC casts would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Waxy casts are most often seen in cases of chronic kidney disease because they can best form in low urine flow states. Although these may also be associated with nephrotic syndrome, waxy casts are observed only in long-standing nephrotic range proteinuria. This patient is very unlikely to have chronic nephrotic syndrome because her symptoms began only 4 days ago.

F) INCORRECT:

WBC casts in urinary sediment are strongly associated with pyelonephritis, although they are not pathognomonic. This patient is afebrile and has no history that might indicate serious urinary tract infection, making pyelonephritis very unlikely. Other causes of WBC casts could include interstitial nephritis or poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. Interstitial nephritis is most commonly associated with a hypersensitivity reaction to NSAIDs, penicillins, or sulfa drugs, none of which have been taken by the patient. This patient has no history of a preceding URTI, which makes poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis highly unlikely. Also, glomerulonephritis classically causes red or cola-colored urine, whereas this patient has yellow urine.

G) INCORRECT:

Hyaline casts are the most commonly observed casts in urine sediment analysis. Their presence is nonspecific. They are commonly seen in healthy individuals who have recently exercised vigorously or been dehydrated.
questions.hint: Edema in combination with frothy urine in a child is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease, which is most likely this child's diagnosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of increasing swelling around her eyes for the past 3 days. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows periorbital edema and abdominal distention with shifting dullness. Laboratory studies show a serum albumin of 2 g/dL and a serum cholesterol concentration of 290 mg/dL.
