Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria and fatty casts. Histological examination of a kidney biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Granular subepithelial deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence
Deposits of IgG and C3 at the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluoresence
Subepithelial dense deposits on electron microscopy
Effacement of foot processes of podocytes on light microscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granular subepithelial deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence are seen in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). PSGN is characteristically preceded by an infection with group A beta-hemolytic streptococci 1–6 weeks before the onset of edema. Moreover, it usually manifests with nephritic sediment rather than the nephrotic sediment seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Mesangial proliferation is seen with light microscopy in IgA nephropathy, which usually manifests with nephritic sediment during or immediately following an infection. IgA nephropathy may also be associated with Henoch-Schönlein purpura. Additional findings include mesangial IgA deposits on immunofluorescence and mesangial immune complex deposits on electron microscopy. This patient's nephrotic sediment is not consistent with IgA nephropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Deposits of IgG and C3 at the glomerular basement membrane can be seen membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, which is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and dysregulation in the complement pathway (complement-mediated MPGN). It is not commonly seen in children and while it can also present with features of nephrotic syndrome, features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hematuria) would also be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Subepithelial dense deposits ('spike and dome' appearance) on electron microscopy are seen in membranous nephropathy, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in Caucasian adults. Additional findings of membranous nephropathy include thickened glomerular capillary loops on light microscopy. Membranous nephropathy also presents with nephrotic syndrome but is not commonly seen in children.

E) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease, which this patient has, is characterized by effacement of foot processes of the podocytes. However, this can only be seen on electron microscopy and would not be visualized with light microscopy. Effacement of foot processes of podocytes is also seen in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which can cause nephrotic syndrome but is not the most common cause in children.

F) CORRECT:

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (especially < 10 years of age). Most cases are idiopathic, but it may occasionally be triggered by a recent infection, immunization, or neoplasm (lymphoma). Circulating cytokines can cause effacement of podocytes that is visible on electron microscopy. However, glomeruli appear normal on light microscopy. Minimal change disease responds very well to corticosteroids and has a good prognosis, which is why a renal biopsy is usually not indicated for diagnosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tissue obtained from renal biopsy (H&E stain; high magnification)

The basement membrane of the glomerulus is intact, the mesangium does not show proliferation. The capillary lumens are visible and there are no vascular changes.

This is the typical appearance of a glomerulus in minimal change disease.
questions.hint: The combination of large proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia indicates nephrotic syndrome. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man comes to the physician for a 4-week history of swollen legs. He has difficulty putting on socks because of the swelling. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with sleep apnea. He takes no medications. He emigrated from Guatemala with his family when he was a child. He is 171 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 115 kg (253 lb); BMI is 39 kg/m2. His pulse is 91/min and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital and bilateral lower extremity edema.


Serum



Albumin
3.1 g/dL


Total cholesterol
312 mg/dL


Urine



Blood
negative


Protein
+4


RBC
1-2/hpf


RBC cast
negative


Fatty casts
numerous


A renal biopsy is obtained. Which of the following is most likely to be seen under light microscopy of the patient's renal biopsy specimen?

choices.text: Fibrin crescents within the glomerular space

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's nephrotic syndrome is most likely due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which appears as segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis under light microscopy. FSGS can be primary (i.e., idiopathic), or secondary to another condition (e.g., obesity, heroin use, sickle cell disease, HIV). Without immunosuppressive treatment, FSGS usually leads to end-stage renal disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (PAS stain; very high magnification)

A cross-section of a glomerulus is visible at the center of the image. The perihilar region is hypercellular and contains hyaline deposits (examples indicated by blue overlay). Loss of the capillary lumens and diffuse sclerosis is also present.

These are the typical features of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (perihilar type).

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrin crescents within the glomerular space are a characteristic finding on kidney biopsy in patients with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Although RPGN may also cause hypertension and edema, it would typically manifest with decreased urine output, gross hematuria, and nephritic sediment with RBC casts on urinalysis. Furthermore, RPGN is usually secondary to an underlying renal condition such as Goodpasture syndrome, immune complex glomerulonephritis (e.g., lupus nephritis), or glomerulonephritis associated with vasculitis (e.g., granulomatosis with polyangiitis), of which this patient does not have any evidence.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

C) INCORRECT:

Thickened glomerular capillary loops are typical biopsy findings in patients with membranous nephropathy (MN), which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in white populations. MN has a strong correlation with hepatitis B and C, as well as systemic lupus erythematosus and solid tumors, none of which are seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy sample (PAS stain; 550× magnification)

There is diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (blue overlay) and capillaries.

These are typical microscopic findings of membranous glomerulopathy (most common glomerulonephritis in adults).

D) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic nodules within the glomeruli (known as Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules) in combination with thickening of the glomerular basement membrane is typical of diabetic nephropathy. Although later stages of this disease can manifest with nephrotic syndrome, as seen in this patient, he has no history of diabetes mellitus, making another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain; high magnification)

A cross-section of a glomerulus can be seen (dashed outline), featuring a thickened glomerular basement membrane and containing abundant pink, hyaline depositions of PAS-positive material (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules or nodular glomerulosclerosis; examples indicated by yellow overlay). Various tubules and vessels surround the glomerulus. An arteriole with distinct hyaline deposits is located above the glomerulus (hyaline arteriolosclerosis; blue overlay).

Nodular glomerulosclerosis combined with hyaline arteriolosclerosis is a typical feature seen in diabetic glomerulopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Amyloid deposition in the mesangium is characteristic of renal involvement in amyloidosis. While the kidney is the most commonly involved organ in amyloidosis, this patient does not have any other features of amyloidosis (e.g., cardiomyopathy, macroglossia). Furthermore, this patient has no history of conditions that predispose to amyloid deposition (e.g., multiple myeloma, rheumatoid arthritis).
Image Description:

Microscopic image of kidney tissue (Congo red stain, approx. 300x)

Two glomeruli containing abnormal hyaline depositions (arrow) are seen in the center of the image.
The interstitial tissue exhibits identical depositions (arrowheads).

Hyaline depositions that stain with Congo red are suggestive of amyloidosis. A definitive diagnosis can only be made by subjecting the sample to polarizing light microscopy.
questions.hint: This patient has several features of nephrotic syndrome, including swelling of the face and extremities, hypoalbuminemia, hypercholesterolemia, obesity, and heavy proteinuria (4+ on urine dipstick). The most likely diagnosis is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in Hispanic populations and is associated with obesity.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-week history of abdominal distension and swelling of the face and lower extremities. The patient notes that during this period her urine became frothy and the overall output has decreased. She was diagnosed with Crohn disease at the age of 22 years and has had multiple flares treated with systemic corticosteroids. One year ago, she underwent carpal tunnel release surgery for median nerve compression. Current medications are azathioprine and loperamide. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her blood pressure is 142/83 mmHg. She is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Physical examination shows generalized pitting edema, moderate ascites, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly. Serum studies show an albumin concentration of 2.9 g/dL, a total cholesterol concentration of 270 mg/dL, and a total bilirubin concentration of 0.2 mg/dL. A urine dipstick test shows 4+ proteinuria. A renal biopsy in this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Crescentic proliferation of glomerular parietal cells on light microscopy and linear intramembranous IgG deposits on immunofluorescence microscopy
Thickened glomerular basement membrane on light microscopy and subepithelial dense deposits on electron microscopy
Mesangial deposits that exhibit apple-green birefringence on polarized light microscopy
Eosinophilic nodular sclerosis within glomeruli on light microscopy
Mesangial IgA immune complex deposits on immunofluorescence microscopy
Segmental sclerosis of glomeruli on light microscopy and podocyte foot process effacement on electron microscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crescentic proliferation of glomerular parietal cells with linear intramembranous IgG deposits is characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) due to Goodpasture syndrome. RPGN results in nephritic syndrome rather than nephrotic syndrome. Moreover, hematuria is present on a urine dipstick test; and neither hypoalbuminemia nor hyperlipidemia is seen in nephritic syndrome. Additionally, patients with Goodpasture syndrome would also have hemoptysis, cough, and/or dyspnea, which are not reported by this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

B) INCORRECT:

Thickened glomerular basement membrane with subepithelial dense deposits is characteristic of membranous nephropathy, which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in white adults. Membranous nephropathy can be secondary to hepatitis B or hepatitis C, which may result in splenomegaly and ascites (due to liver cirrhosis) as seen here. However, the normal bilirubin levels in this patient make liver cirrhosis unlikely; also, her past history suggests a different etiology.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy sample (PAS stain; 550× magnification)

There is diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (blue overlay) and capillaries.

These are typical microscopic findings of membranous glomerulopathy (most common glomerulonephritis in adults).

C) CORRECT:

Deposits that exhibit apple-green birefringence on polarized light microscopy using the Congo red stain are characteristic of amyloidosis, which is caused by extracellular deposition of insoluble protein fibrils (amyloid). Systemic amyloidosis can result from light-chain amyloid deposition (AL amyloidosis or primary amyloidosis) in the case of plasma cell dyscrasias, or serum amyloid associated-protein deposition (AA amyloidosis or secondary amyloidosis) in the case of chronic inflammatory diseases (e.g., Crohn disease; as seen here) and chronic infections. The kidneys are the most commonly affected organs in systemic amyloidosis and amyloid deposits are typically located in the mesangium, which can cause nephrotic syndrome. Less common manifestations of renal amyloidosis include type 2 renal tubular acidosis and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.
Image Description:

Polarized light photomicrograph of the kidney (Congo red stain; 300x magnification)

The sediments in the area of the glomeruli and renal interstitium (white arrow; white arrowheads) appear birefringent in the polarized light and bright green in color (characteristic of amyloids).

These are both key diagnostic features of amyloid sediments.

D) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic nodular sclerosis within glomeruli (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions) is characteristic of diabetic nephropathy, which is the leading cause of end-stage renal disease in middle and high-income countries and can result in nephrotic syndrome. However, diabetic nephropathy occurs after several years of uncontrolled hyperglycemia. This patient does not have a history of diabetes mellitus or clinical features suggestive of undiagnosed diabetes mellitus (e.g., fatigue, polyuria, polydipsia). This patient's hepatosplenomegaly and past medical history suggest a different cause for her nephrotic syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney autopsy specimen (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Nodular glomerulosclerosis in diabetic nephropathy (Kimmelstiel-Wilson syndrome) displays with mesangial thickening due to nodular, hyaline deposits (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions; yellow overlay) within the glomerulus (blue overlay). Further findings include thickening of the tubular basement membranes, tubular atrophy, and an increase of interstitial connective tissue between renal tubules (interstitial fibrosis).

Nodular glomerulosclerosis takes a decade or longer to develop in diabetes mellitus.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

Mesangial IgA immune complex deposits are characteristic of IgA nephropathy, the most common cause of idiopathic glomerulonephritis worldwide. IgA nephropathy results in nephritic syndrome rather than nephrotic syndrome. Moreover, hematuria would be present on a urine dipstick test; and neither hypoalbuminemia nor hyperlipidemia is present in nephritic syndrome. In addition, patients with IgA nephropathy typically develop symptoms following a gastrointestinal or respiratory infection; this patient has not reported any recent infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

F) INCORRECT:

Segmental sclerosis of the glomeruli with podocyte foot process effacement is characteristic of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in African American and Hispanic adults. This patient has nephrotic syndrome, but her hepatosplenomegaly and past history suggest a different cause for nephrotic syndrome.
Image Description:

Electron micrograph

Ultrastructural findings of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis showing podocyte foot process effacement (thin black arrows) and protein reabsorption droplet (white arrow). Endothelial cells show tubuloreticular inclusions in the upper right-hand corner (star)

Effacement of podocyte foot processes is commonly seen in electron microscopy samples of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.
questions.hint: Hyperlipidemia, hypoalbuminemia, massive proteinuria, and anasarca indicate nephrotic syndrome. This patient's organomegaly (hepatomegaly, splenomegaly), past history of carpal tunnel syndrome, and Crohn disease are consistent with systemic amyloidosis, the most likely etiology for her presentation.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office because of bilateral ankle swelling that occurred overnight. He has stopped wearing socks because they feel too tight. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus treated with insulin. He has received all scheduled immunizations. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 112/75 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. There is moderate scrotal edema, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
5000/mm3



Platelet count
240,000/mm3



Serum



 Urea nitrogen
36 mg/dL


 Glucose
77 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


 Albumin

2.6 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
negative


 Glucose
negative


 Protein

4+


 RBC
none


 WBC
0–1/hpf


 Fatty casts

numerous


Treatment with prednisone is begun. Over the following weeks, there is a significant improvement in the patient's peripheral edema and urinalysis findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nodular glomerulosclerosis is typically seen in patients with diabetic nephropathy, which can manifest with nephrotic syndrome. Although this young patient has type 1 diabetes mellitus, diabetic nephropathy is only expected in more advanced stages of the disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) most commonly manifests with nephritic rather than nephrotic syndrome and is usually associated with hepatitis C and hepatitis B infection, autoimmune diseases, and monoclonal gammopathies, none of which are seen here. Although MPGN can manifest with nephrotic-range proteinuria in severe cases, features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hematuria, hypertension, elevated creatinine) would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy can cause nephrotic syndrome, but this condition is more common in young adults and typically manifests with gross hematuria, flank pain, and features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hypertension, increased creatinine). In addition, IgA nephropathy is often preceded by upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infections, neither of which is seen here.

D) CORRECT:

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Immunosuppressive therapy is recommended for all patients with MCD; glucocorticoid therapy (e.g., with prednisone) is considered the first-line treatment, as most patients improve with this regimen alone. If complete remission does not occur, higher doses of steroid therapy or alternative immunosuppressive agents (e.g., cyclophosphamide, calcineurin inhibitors) may be needed. Edema should be controlled by sodium restriction and careful monitoring of fluid input and output.

MCD has also been associated with hematologic malignancies (e.g., Hodgkin lymphoma).

E) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can cause nephrotic syndrome. However, this condition is more common in adults and most frequently occurs in association with heroin use, HIV infection, obesity, and sickle cell disease, none of which are seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy can manifest with nephrotic syndrome, which this patient has. However, this condition is more common in adults and is often secondary to infections (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C), autoimmune diseases, solid tumors, and medications (e.g., NSAIDs), none of which are seen here.
questions.hint: This patient's history of edema, hypoalbuminemia, proteinuria, and fatty casts on urinalysis indicates nephrotic syndrome. In this patient, a renal biopsy would most likely show glomeruli with a normal appearance on light microscopy and effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 4 hours after the sudden onset of flank pain and nausea. Initially, the pain was limited to her left flank, but 1 hour ago, her right flank also started to hurt. During this time, she also noticed blood in her urine and gradually worsening swelling of her legs. She was diagnosed with membranous nephropathy 5 months ago, for which she takes enalapril and rituximab. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 137/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen, bilateral flank tenderness, and 2+ pitting edema of both lower extremities. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Lactate dehydrogenase
750 U/L


 Urea nitrogen
30 mg/dL


 Creatinine
2.8 mg/dL


 Albumin
1.8 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
3+


 Protein
4+


 WBC
0–1/hpf


 Protein/creatinine ratio
7.6 (N ≤ 0.2)


Two weeks ago, her serum creatinine concentration and blood urea nitrogen were 1.5 mg/dL and 19 mg/dL, respectively. Abdominal ultrasonography shows bilaterally enlarged kidneys. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Nephrotic syndrome is associated with acquired hypercoagulability due to urinary loss of proteins (e.g., antithrombin III) and thereby predisposes affected individuals to thrombotic complications such as renal vein thrombosis (RVT). MR venography is the diagnostic modality of choice in patients with AKI or renal impairment (eGFR < 30 ml/min/1.73 m2). While selective renal venography is the gold standard and CT angiography the diagnostic test of choice in patients with suspected acute bilateral RVT, both studies require iodinated contrast media, which would put this patient at risk for contrast-induced nephropathy. Other common causes of RVT include malignancy and trauma.

Note that unilateral RVTs secondary to nephrotic syndrome are most commonly chronic, asymptomatic, and identified incidentally (e.g., during evaluation of a pulmonary embolism).

B) INCORRECT:

24-hour urine profile is indicated in the metabolic surveillance of patients with recurrent nephrolithiasis, which may manifest with hematuria, flank pain, and AKI. However, this patient is in need of an urgent imaging study to confirm the diagnosis of acute bilateral renal vein thrombosis, which warrants another diagnostic test.

C) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is the imaging modality of choice in the diagnosis of renal vein thrombosis in patients with sufficient renal function (eGFR > 30 mL/min/1.73 m2) and without AKI. This patient has AKI and is consequently at increased risk for contrast-induced nephropathy, so another diagnostic approach is more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal scintigraphy assesses the anatomy and function of the kidneys. Indications in adults include the monitoring of renal transplants and screening for renal artery stenosis. Renal scintigraphy has no role in the diagnosis of acute, bilateral renal vein thrombosis.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of membranous nephropathy presents with nephrotic syndrome (urine protein/creatinine ratio > 3.5 g/g, hypoalbuminemia, edema). Sudden development of bilateral flank pain, gross hematuria, increased lactate dehydrogenase, acute kidney injury (AKI; increased creatinine and blood urea nitrogen), and bilateral renal enlargement is suggestive of bilateral acute renal vein thrombosis.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for an elevated serum creatinine level. The finding was detected during an outpatient workup for progressive edema, which began as mild swelling several months ago. Her medical history includes hypertension, hypothyroidism, osteoarthritis, and fibromyalgia. Her medications are hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily, amlodipine 5 mg daily, levothyroxine 75 μg daily, and ibuprofen 600 mg twice daily.
On examination, her blood pressure is 133/64 mm Hg, her heart rate is 86 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute. Her cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Anasarca is present.
On laboratory testing, her serum creatinine level is 1.7 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1), her albumin level is 2.3 g/dL (3.5–5.5), and her potassium level is 4.9 mEq/liter (3.5–5.0). Urine microscopy shows 15 to 20 white cells per high-power field (0–2), and her 24-hour urine protein excretion is 6400 mg/24 hours (<150).
Which one of the following initial management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone has been touted as a diuretic that reduces proteinuria, but it may cause hyperkalemia in the setting of reduced renal function. A better strategy would be to treat the underlying cause and use loop diuretics as necessary for symptomatic edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Although prednisone is the most appropriate initial treatment for idiopathic minimal-change disease, its use would be appropriate only if resolution did not occur after the nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug is discontinued.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has symptoms of nephrotic syndrome, but she has also had a decline in kidney function, and the urine test results are suggestive of acute interstitial nephritis. This constellation of symptoms can occur with use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), which can lead to either disorder or cause both simultaneously. Nephrotic syndrome linked to the use of NSAIDs may be a manifestation of either minimal change disease or membranous nephropathy. Discontinuation of the NSAIDs is critical to the management of this disorder.

Imaging and renal biopsy should be pursued if the patient does not improve promptly after discontinuing the ibuprofen.

Key learning point: In older patients who take nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, a potential cause of acute kidney injury with significant proteinuria is minimal-change disease, with or without interstitial nephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine may cause peripheral edema, but the effect is rarely substantial and does not lead to kidney injury; consequently, the drug does not need to be discontinued.

E) INCORRECT:

The sudden onset of nephrotic syndrome is unlikely to be attributable to renal arterial disease. Nephrotic syndrome is a hypercoagulable state, and patients are at risk for thromboembolism and, in particular, renal vein thrombosis. A renal Doppler study is reasonable and can be pursued if the patient has associated symptoms such as flank pain or hematuria.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman reports progressive lower-extremity swelling and weight gain of at least 13 kg during the past 3 months. The swelling began in the feet and ankles but progressed to the lower extremities, groin area, and lower abdominal wall. She denies dyspnea and has noticed no changes in the color or amount of her urine. She has diet-controlled type 2 diabetes and a history of moderately increased albuminuria in the range of 50 to 100 mg/g. Otherwise, she has been healthy and takes no medications.
Her blood pressure is 164/76 mm Hg, her heart rate is 96 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 98% while she is breathing ambient air. Funduscopic and cardiopulmonary examinations are unremarkable. The patient has substantial pitting edema involving the sacral area, lower abdominal wall, and both lower extremities.
Urine microscopy shows waxy casts and oval fat droplets but no erythrocytes. Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Screening for HIV, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and syphilis is negative. Results of serum and urine protein electrophoresis show no evidence of monoclonal gammopathy.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Doppler ultrasound of the renal arteries

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen can identify structural causes of edema, such as inferior vena cava thrombosis or lymphatic obstruction, but these abnormalities do not cause nephrotic syndrome. Certain abdominal tumors (e.g., colorectal carcinoma, gastric cancer, lymphoma) can cause nephrotic syndrome, but a different diagnostic step should be performed first in this patient to guide further workup.

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is used to assess for cardiac dysfunction and infective endocarditis. Congestive heart failure (CHF) can cause edema due to a sodium-avid state, but it does not cause lipiduria and only results in mild proteinuria as a result of congestive nephropathy (typically < 1 g/day or < 1000 mg/g on a spot urine protein-to-creatinine ratio). This degree of proteinuria is generally not significant enough to cause hypoalbuminemia, and patients with congestive nephropathy would be expected to have azotemia and other features of CHF (e.g., dyspnea, jugular distention). Nephrotic syndrome from infective endocarditis is rare, and there are no findings to suggest infective endocarditis.

C) CORRECT:

The rapid onset of overt nephrotic syndrome — characterized by edema, hypoalbuminemia, proteinuria, and hyperlipidemia — warrants a kidney biopsy to make an accurate diagnosis and direct further management.

The rapid onset of overt nephrotic syndrome is not typical of diabetic nephropathy, which is a slowly progressive disease with increasing levels of albuminuria during a period of years. When patients with or without type 2 diabetes develop a rapid decline in renal function, acceleration in proteinuria, or an active urinary sediment, they require prompt additional evaluation. Those findings could be due to either a nondiabetic kidney disease superimposed on diabetic nephropathy or another glomerular disease without evidence of diabetic nephropathy. Two-thirds of the patients who have type 2 diabetes and these extra findings have an additional disorder as the underlying cause.

Uncontrolled hypertension is a contraindication for kidney biopsy because of the risk of bleeding. Patients with systolic blood pressure > 140 mm Hg should receive antihypertensive therapy before the procedure.

Key learning point: Rapid-onset nephrotic syndrome is not typical of diabetic nephropathy and requires further evaluation with kidney biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

A 24-hour urine protein collection > 3500 mg indicates nephrotic range proteinuria, and this patient's presentation is consistent with nephrotic syndrome. A spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio or urine protein-to-creatinine ratio is a convenient surrogate to approximately measure the amount of albumin or protein excreted per day in urine, but it is not as accurate as quantification performed via 24-hour urine collection (especially at very high levels of proteinuria). The primary urine protein in nephrotic syndrome is albumin, and measuring the urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio will not change this patient's management.

E) INCORRECT:

Doppler ultrasound of the renal arteries is used to evaluate flow in the renal arteries. This test is appropriate when renovascular disease is suspected. Although proteinuria can occur with renovascular disease from damage to glomeruli, renovascular disease does not cause nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis reports a one-year history of gradually progressive lower-extremity edema despite treatment with furosemide and metolazone. Echocardiography shows no evidence of heart disease.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Anti-double-stranded DNA, complement C3, and complement C4 results are normal. A 24-hour urine collection reveals 5800 mg of protein (reference range, <150). Urine microscopy identifies 2 red cells per high-power field (0–2).
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s proteinuria and diminished kidney function?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Amyloidosis refers to the deposition of low-molecular-weight fibrils in extracellular tissue. The two most common forms of systemic amyloidosis are primary (AL) amyloidosis and secondary or reactive (AA) amyloidosis. Reactive systemic (AA) amyloidosis can complicate chronic inflammatory disorders that are associated with a sustained acute-phase response, such as rheumatoid arthritis, periodic fever syndromes, inflammatory bowel disease, and tuberculosis. The major sites of amyloid deposition are the kidneys, heart, and liver; however, in some conditions, amyloid deposition can be limited to one organ, such as the kidney.

This patient has nephrotic syndrome and a polyclonal gammopathy without an M spike in the setting of chronic inflammation or infection; this constellation of findings is characteristic of a secondary cause of amyloidosis (AA).

Key learning point: In a patient with a chronic inflammatory disorder or a chronic infectious disease, the most likely cause of nephrotic syndrome is reactive systemic (AA) amyloidosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Lupus nephritis is unlikely in the setting of normal complement levels and in the absence of antibodies to double-stranded DNA.

C) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A (IgA) nephropathy is typically characterized by microscopic hematuria. Patients may develop nephrotic-range proteinuria with time, but nephrotic syndrome is an unusual presentation for IgA nephropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Post-infectious glomerulonephritis is usually characterized by depressed serum complement levels and an active urine sediment, including hematuria, red-cell casts, and mild-to-moderate proteinuria.

E) INCORRECT:

Characteristic features of chronic interstitial nephritis include pyuria and proteinuria that is below 2000 mg per day. Nephrotic syndrome is rarely associated with interstitial nephritis. An exception is nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, which can cause concurrent interstitial nephritis and nephrotic syndrome from either minimal-change disease or membranous nephropathy.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man is hospitalized with a 6-hour history of acute, constant left-flank pain. He denies fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, or dysuria. He was recently diagnosed with idiopathic membranous nephropathy. He had previously been well without other medical issues. At his most recent evaluation 2 months ago, his serum creatinine level was 1.1 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3). He takes lisinopril 40 mg daily.
On examination, his blood pressure is 136/84 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 90 beats per minute. He is afebrile and weighs 72 kg. He has persistent left-flank tenderness without rebound and normal bowel sounds, with no palpable abdominal masses. He has 3+ bilateral pitting edema.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
7000
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13.0
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
175,000
150,000–350,000



Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.5
0.8–1.3


Albumin (g/dL)
1.8
3.5–5.5


His urinalysis shows 5 white cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) and 20 red cells per high-power field (0–2). His urine protein-to-creatinine ratio is 8.1 mg/mg (reference range, <0.2).
Which one of the following imaging studies is most appropriate to establish a diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Noncontrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Technetium-99m-labeled dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) renal scintigraphy can be useful for determining the relative contribution of each kidney to total renal function (split renal function), but it has no role in the evaluation of suspected renal-vein thrombosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Noncontrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis is used to detect nephrolithiasis, which is another possible diagnosis in this case, given the patient's flank pain and hematuria. However, this study cannot evaluate for the more likely diagnosis of renal-vein thrombosis. CT angiography is the better test to assess for renal-vein thrombosis and would also show nephrolithiasis if it was present.

C) INCORRECT:

A routine kidney ultrasound does not include an assessment of the vasculature and thus cannot be used to make the diagnosis of renal-vein thrombosis. Even Doppler ultrasonography would not be the study of choice in this patient. Doppler ultrasonography is sometimes used to image the renal vessels if a patient has significant renal dysfunction or an allergy that precludes the use of iodinated contrast or gadolinium, but this patient has only mild renal dysfunction, and there is no suggestion of an allergy. Furthermore, Doppler ultrasonography is the study of choice to evaluate the renal veins in kidney transplants, but it may be technically difficult to perform in native kidneys and has low sensitivity and specificity in this setting; thus, a negative study in this patient would not be adequate to rule out the diagnosis of renal-vein thrombosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Retrograde pyelography is used to detect nephrolithiasis, which is another possible diagnosis in this case, given the patient's flank pain and hematuria. However, this study cannot evaluate for the more likely diagnosis of renal-vein thrombosis. CT angiography is the better test to assess for renal-vein thrombosis and would also show nephrolithiasis if it was present.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with nephrotic syndrome are at increased risk for venous thrombosis, including renal-vein thrombosis. The symptoms of flank pain, gross or microscopic hematuria, and worsening kidney function suggest acute renal-vein thrombosis.

Historically, the gold-standard diagnostic test for renal-vein thrombosis was selective renal venography, but now, with the advent of less-invasive techniques, this strategy is less commonly used. Instead, CT angiography is the recommended study. The renal veins can be well visualized during venous phase imaging after contrast, and a filling defect will be identified if there is venous thrombosis. CT angiography has very high sensitivity and specificity for this condition. In addition, it will also detect other potential causes of hematuria and flank pain, including renal-artery defects, kidney masses, and stones. Magnetic resonance angiography can also be used in this setting, but it will not identify kidney stones.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial diagnostic test to evaluate a patient with nephrotic syndrome and suspected renal-vein thrombosis is CT angiography.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with diffuse swelling that developed rapidly over the course of several days. He is diagnosed with the nephrotic syndrome, and a renal biopsy reveals features consistent with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.
He is afebrile, and his blood pressure is 158/86 mm Hg. Other than the presence of anasarca, the physical examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory studies reveal a urinary protein level of 9600 mg/24 hr (reference range, <150). A test for HIV infection is negative, as is testing for APOL1 risk alleles.
In addition to initiating therapy with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If a patient with primary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis does not respond to prednisone or has contraindications to it, initial treatment with a calcineurin inhibitor, such as cyclosporine or tacrolimus, is reasonable to consider.

B) INCORRECT:

Mycophenolate mofetil and cyclophosphamide have been used to treat primary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis but are not considered first-line therapy.

C) CORRECT:

Prednisone is the first-line therapy for primary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), along with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor to reduce proteinuria. The clinical features of the nephrotic syndrome include hypoalbuminemia, edema, and nephrotic-range proteinuria (>3500 mg/24 hr). Hyperlipidemia is also commonly seen, as is lipiduria with fatty casts.

Secondary FSGS may cause nephrotic-range proteinuria without other features of the nephrotic syndrome and with a more gradual onset. In secondary FSGS, treatment with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor and good blood pressure control without immunosuppressive therapy is the standard of care.

Key learning point: In addition to initiating therapy with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, the most appropriate initial treatment for primary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is prednisone.

D) INCORRECT:

If a patient with primary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis does not respond to prednisone or has contraindications to it, initial treatment with a calcineurin inhibitor, such as cyclosporine or tacrolimus, is reasonable to consider.

E) INCORRECT:

Mycophenolate mofetil and cyclophosphamide have been used to treat primary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis but are not considered first-line therapy.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia reports painless, bilateral lower-extremity edema during the past 2 weeks. He denies dyspnea and chest pain. His current medications are amlodipine 5 mg daily, atorvastatin 20 mg daily, and aspirin 81 mg daily.
The patient has a temperature of 37.2°C, a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 148/88 mm Hg. He appears comfortable. Examinations of the heart, lungs, and abdomen are unremarkable. His jugular venous pressure is 1 cm above the clavicle at 45 degrees. There is 3+ pitting edema of both lower extremities to the knees but no rashes or calf tenderness to palpation.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Urinalysis reveals 4+ protein and trace blood. Fatty casts are noted on urine microscopy.
Which one of the following observations is this patient most likely to report?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The appearance of the urine often yields clues about the underlying kidney disorder, although patient reports regarding the urine appearance may be unreliable. Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by edema, hypoalbuminemia, nephrotic-range proteinuria (typically >3.5 g/day), and hyperlipidemia. Patients with nephrotic-range proteinuria typically describe foamy urine.

In patients with heavy proteinuria, the proximal tubular cells reabsorb filtered lipoproteins and proteins. On microscopy, desquamated proximal tubular cells laden with lipid can appear as either oval fat bodies or lipid-containing granular casts (fatty casts). These fat droplets look like Maltese crosses under polarized light.

Key learning point: The typical appearance of urine in a patient with nephrotic syndrome is foamy urine.

B) INCORRECT:

Muddy, darkened urine is suggestive of acute tubular necrosis and is related to the presence of granular casts in the urine.

C) INCORRECT:

Grains in the urine can be an indicator of crystalluria and urolithiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Red urine that is negative for blood by dipstick can be due to certain medications or ingestion of large amounts of beets (beeturia).

When the urinary dipstick is positive for blood, this may be from hemoglobin or myoglobin. If there are red cells evident by microscopy, then this is from hematuria. Hematuria can result from bleeding anywhere along the urinary tract from the glomerular basement membrane to the urethra. If there are no red cells evident by microscopy, then the positive dipstick represents either free hemoglobin or myoglobin. Here, the clinical scenario will help differentiate the two. If there is evidence of hemolysis including anemia, abnormalities on the blood smear, and a low haptoglobin, the source of the positive dipstick is likely from hemoglobinuria. If there is a clinical history consistent with muscle injury and the serum creatine kinase level is elevated, then the positive dipstick is from myoglobinuria in the setting of rhabdomyolysis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cloudy urine and dysuria are symptoms of a urinary tract infection.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with fatigue, irritability, and a headache. Her parents note she has gained roughly 2.5 kg during the past 2 weeks and that her shoes no longer fit on her feet. She had an upper respiratory tract infection a few weeks ago and was treated with a 10-day course of amoxicillin.
She is currently afebrile, her heart rate is 91 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 95/53 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals periorbital edema, a distended abdomen, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
131
135–147


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.7
3.4–4.7


Chloride (mEq/liter)
102
97–107


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
24
22–26


Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s hyponatremia?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal losses can lead to hyponatremia. In this setting, volume depletion leads to appropriate stimulation of ADH and the RAAS. If rehydration is achieved with dilute fluids, the child may develop hyponatremia. This patient has edema, which suggests a hypervolemic state.

B) INCORRECT:

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion results in normovolemic hyponatremia and should not lead to periorbital or peripheral edema.

C) INCORRECT:

Certain chemotherapeutic and antiepileptic agents can induce normovolemic hyponatremia caused by inappropriate ADH release. Antibiotics have not been reported to have this effect.

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebral salt wasting is a controversial entity that is thought to be a cause of hypovolemic hyponatremia; this extremely rare disorder can be seen with severe central nervous system disorders or after neurosurgical procedures.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has hypervolemic hyponatremia. Hyponatremia is defined as a serum sodium level <135 mEq/liter. Volume status helps to clarify the cause of hyponatremia, and assessment of volume status should be one of the first steps in caring for a patient with hyponatremia. This child has periorbital edema, peripheral edema, and possibly ascites given the abdominal distention, which may be seen in hypervolemic states. The most common causes of hypervolemic hyponatremia in children are nephrotic syndrome, heart failure, and cirrhosis. Nephrotic syndrome usually occurs in children younger than 6 years of age and often follows an inciting infectious event, such as a respiratory tract infection, but it can also occur with no trigger.

Nephrotic syndrome is diagnosed when a patient has edema, proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hypercholesterolemia. It can cause severe hypoalbuminemia (<2 g/dL). In this setting, the decrease in intravascular oncotic pressure can lead to reduced effective circulating volume and appropriate release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This leads to water and sodium retention. If the child ingests a substantial amount of fluid, hyponatremia may occur. The degree of hyponatremia is typically mild; sodium levels range from 130 to 135 mEq/liter. In addition to fluid restriction, treatment is aimed at the underlying disorder.

Key learning point: The three main causes of hypervolemic hyponatremia in children are liver failure, heart failure, and nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy presents with facial swelling that has progressed for 2 weeks. He has had no fever, vomiting, or diarrhea, but he has seemed fatigued and his appetite is diminished. His pants and shoes are now tight. His weight has increased 4 kg during the past 2 months.
His current blood pressure is 91/47 mm Hg, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. He has edema with pitting in the lower extremities, abdominal ascites, and sacral edema.
A urine dipstick test is positive for 3+ protein and 1+ blood. Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
131
135–147


Potassium (mEq/liter)

3.4–4.7


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)

5–18

0.3–0.7

438

Serum albumin (g/dL)
1.9

Complement C3 (mg/dL)
102
86–184


Complement C4 (mg/dL)

Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is a less common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, particularly those who are < 10 years of age, and is less likely to be glucocorticoid-responsive. Diagnosis requires a renal biopsy, which is generally pursued if a patient is not glucocorticoid-responsive.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has nephrotic syndrome with edema, marked proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hypercholesterolemia.

In young children, minimal-change disease accounts for 77% to 95% of cases of nephrotic syndrome. About 95% of patients with minimal-change disease achieve remission after a course of glucocorticoids, and such a response is predictive of a more benign disease course. A presumptive diagnosis of minimal-change disease can be based on clinical findings. Normal blood pressure, absence of gross hematuria, normal renal function, and normal complement levels are all consistent with minimal-change disease, as is a prompt response to glucocorticoid therapy. Renal biopsy is usually limited to patients who are not glucocorticoid-responsive or have other concerning findings at the time of diagnosis, such as depressed renal function, severe hypertension, or hypocomplementemia.

Key learning point: The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal-change disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Membranous glomerulopathy is a less common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, particularly those who are < 10 years of age, and is less likely to be glucocorticoid-responsive. Diagnosis requires a renal biopsy, which is generally pursued if a patient is not glucocorticoid-responsive.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with immunoglobulin A (IgA) nephropathy have hematuria with or without proteinuria. The most common presentation is gross hematuria within 1 to 2 days of a viral illness. Nephrotic syndrome accompanies IgA nephropathy only very rarely.

E) INCORRECT:

Although lupus nephritis can manifest as nephrotic syndrome, nephritis should lead to hypertension and would not cause hypercholesterolemia. This diagnosis would be very unlikely in a child this age. Lupus nephritis typically results in hypocomplementemia (low levels of complement proteins C3 and C4).

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy presents with swelling around his eyes and scrotum that his mother first noticed 3 days ago. She reports that he recently had a viral upper respiratory infection but has otherwise been healthy.
He appears well nourished and well developed. He is afebrile, and his vital signs are normal for his age. His physical examination, including lung and cardiac evaluations, is unremarkable except for visible, symmetric edema of both of his eyelids and his scrotum.
A spot urine sample shows a protein-to-creatinine ratio of 5 mg/mg, and urinalysis reveals 3+ protein and no blood. Blood testing reveals a serum albumin level of 1.5 g/dL (reference range, 3.5–5.5) and a cholesterol level of 450 mg/dL (<170). A referral to pediatric nephrology is made.
Which one of the following initial therapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tacrolimus is indicated for childhood nephrotic syndrome that is glucocorticoid resistant or as second- or third-line therapy in a child who is glucocorticoid dependent. However, it is not the initial therapy of choice. Tacrolimus can cause calcineurin-inhibitor toxicity which, over time, may lead to a reduction in renal function. Although this medication is sometimes needed for childhood nephrotic syndrome, it is not the first treatment of choice for a child who most likely has minimal change nephrotic syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

An antibiotic such as ceftriaxone would be indicated if a child with new-onset nephrotic syndrome had fever, as these children will have an increased risk for infection related to loss of immunoglobulin in the urine. Although this child had an antecedent viral respiratory infection, he appears well and is afebrile. Thus, antibiotics are not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

If a diuretic is needed for acute and symptomatic control of edema, a loop diuretic, such as furosemide, is typically used rather than a thiazide. However, a diuretic would most often be used along with provision of albumin to promote movement of fluid into the vascular space and then allow diuresis. Although this aspect of care can result in symptomatic improvement, it does not treat the underlying nephrotic syndrome. Furthermore, although this patient has edema on examination, his fluid overload and edema are not causing any current distress, so rapid diuresis is not a first step in his management.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation and laboratory results are consistent with nephrotic syndrome, a disorder that results from podocyte injury and increased permeability of the filtration slit diaphragm of the glomerular capillary. Nephrotic syndrome is commonly preceded by a viral upper respiratory infection. Periorbital edema is often noticed first, followed by edema of the dependent regions, such as the ankles, back, scrotum or penis (in boys), and labia (in girls). Affected patients will also have hyperlipidemia.

Diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome requires the presence of generalized edema, hypoalbuminemia (serum albumin concentration <2.5 g/dL), and high-grade proteinuria (urinary protein excretion >50 mg/kg per day). Given that timed urine collections can be difficult in young children, a spot urine protein-to-creatinine ratio can be used to estimate protein excretion; a ratio >2 mg/mg (or 2000 mg/gram) is consistent with nephrotic-range proteinuria. In adults, the nephrotic range is higher (>3.5 mg/mg), because adults have a greater excretion of creatinine and so a greater ratio is required to reflect this level of proteinuria.

Given the history provided in this case, the patient's nephrotic syndrome is not likely to be associated with another systemic disease. Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of idiopathic nephrotic syndrome in children, and first-line therapy consists of a glucocorticoid, such as prednisone. Because most children with MCD respond well to this treatment, children who present with new onset of nephrotic syndrome are treated presumptively with glucocorticoids. If there is inadequate response to such therapy, a renal biopsy may be indicated to investigate additional etiologies for the proteinuria.

Glucocorticoids are the primary treatment for nephrotic syndrome in children.

Key learning point: In children, the combination of edema, hypoalbuminemia, and high-grade proteinuria is consistent with nephrotic syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclosporine is not used as a primary treatment for nephrotic syndrome. Although it was previously used as a second-line agent, it has fallen out of favor because of its adverse effects and the availability of other, better-tolerated medications.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the office because of a 3-month history of fatigue and weakness. Her hemoglobin A1c concentration was 13.5% 12 weeks ago. Her blood pressure is 152/92 mm Hg. Examination shows lower extremity edema. Serum studies show:


K+

5.1 mEq/L


Phosphorus
5.0 mg/dL


Ca2+

7.8 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
60 mg/dL


Creatinine
2.2 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most appropriate parameter for early detection of this patient’s renal condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of urinary red blood cell casts indicates glomerulonephritis (GN). This finding is caused by the congregation of proteins and RBCs inside the tubules. Clinically, GN can result in red or cola-colored urine, mild edema (due to the relatively limited loss of albumin), and hypertension (i.e., nephritic syndrome). However, diabetic nephropathy classically leads to nephrotic syndrome, not nephritic syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Diabetic nephropathy leads to nephrotic syndrome, which typically manifests with hypoproteinemia. However, total protein is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only decreases once there is significant glomerular damage.

C) CORRECT:

Microalbuminuria is the earliest diagnostic sign of diabetic nephropathy. Progression of glomerular damage (nodular glomerulosclerosis) leads to increased urinary loss of albumin, which can manifest as nephrotic syndrome. The extent of albuminuria in patients with diabetic nephropathy also correlates with the risk of future cardiovascular events. ACE inhibitors can prevent the progression of albuminuria in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum urea nitrogen (BUN) is routinely measured as part of renal function testing in patients with diabetic nephropathy and other forms of chronic kidney disease. However, BUN is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only rises once the glomerular filtration rate significantly deteriorates.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine is routinely measured as part of renal function testing in patients with diabetic nephropathy and other forms of chronic kidney disease. However, it is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only rises once the glomerular filtration rate significantly deteriorates.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents with features of diabetic nephropathy (elevated creatinine and BUN levels, arterial hypertension, electrolyte abnormalities, edema).

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office because of bilateral ankle swelling that occurred overnight. He has stopped wearing socks because they feel too tight. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus treated with insulin. There is moderate scrotal edema, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Serum studies show:


Urea nitrogen
36 mg/dL


Glucose
77 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


Albumin
2.6 mg/dL


Urinalysis discloses 4+ protein and numerous fatty casts. Treatment with prednisone is begun. Over the following weeks, there is a significant improvement in the patient's peripheral edema and urinalysis findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nodular glomerulosclerosis is typically seen in patients with diabetic nephropathy, which can manifest with nephrotic syndrome. Although this young patient has type 1 diabetes mellitus, diabetic nephropathy is only expected in more advanced stages of the disease.

B) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy can cause nephrotic syndrome, but this condition is more common in young adults and typically manifests with gross hematuria, flank pain, and features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hypertension, increased creatinine). In addition, IgA nephropathy is often preceded by upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infections, neither of which is seen here.

C) CORRECT:

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Immunosuppressive therapy is recommended for all patients with MCD; glucocorticoid therapy (e.g., with prednisone) is considered the first-line treatment, as most patients improve with this regimen alone. If complete remission does not occur, higher doses of steroid therapy or alternative immunosuppressive agents (e.g., cyclophosphamide, calcineurin inhibitors) may be needed. Edema should be controlled by sodium restriction and careful monitoring of fluid input and output.

MCD has also been associated with hematologic malignancies (e.g., Hodgkin lymphoma).

Key learning point: Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and typically responds well to corticosteroid therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can cause nephrotic syndrome. However, this condition is more common in adults and most frequently occurs in association with heroin use, HIV infection, obesity, and sickle cell disease, none of which are seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy can manifest with nephrotic syndrome, which this patient has. However, this condition is more common in adults and is often secondary to infections (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C), autoimmune diseases, solid tumors, and medications (e.g., NSAIDs), none of which are seen here.
questions.hint: This patient's history of edema, hypoalbuminemia, proteinuria, and fatty casts on urinalysis indicates nephrotic syndrome. In this patient, a renal biopsy would most likely show glomeruli with a normal appearance on light microscopy and effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to persistent swelling around his eyelids for the past two weeks, most prominent in the morning. He has also developed swelling in his ankles and abdomen. He denies any recent infections, joint pains, or rashes. On examination, he appears well with marked periorbital edema and mild pedal edema. Cardiac auscultation is normal (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Albumin
22 g/L
34 - 56 g/L

8.9 mmol/L
< 5.1 mmol/L


Urine

3+

Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This pediatric patient presents with periorbital and peripheral edema due to significant protein loss through the kidneys, as indicated by heavy proteinuria. The resultant hypoalbuminemia decreases plasma oncotic pressure, facilitating fluid movement into interstitial spaces and causing edema. The liver compensates by increasing lipoprotein synthesis, leading to hypercholesterolemia. These clinical and laboratory findings are consistent with nephrotic syndrome, commonly due to minimal change disease in children. The absence of hematuria further supports this diagnosis, distinguishing it from nephritic syndromes.

Key learning point: Nephrotic syndrome in children is characterized by hypoalbuminemia, hypercholesterolemia, and edema, and is the most likely diagnosis in a child presenting with these symptoms and lab findings.

B) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is associated with hematuria, often following an upper respiratory infection. The absence of hematuria and the presence of significant proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia suggest a nephrotic syndrome rather than IgA nephropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatic cirrhosis can cause edema due to hypoalbuminemia from decreased hepatic synthesis. However, the significant proteinuria indicates renal protein loss, and the elevated cholesterol level aligns with nephrotic syndrome. The patient's age and lack of cirrhosis-specific features further argue against this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis typically follows a streptococcal infection and presents with nephritic syndrome, including hematuria and mild proteinuria. The absence of recent infections and hematuria, along with the presence of heavy proteinuria and hypercholesterolemia, makes this diagnosis unlikely.

A) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy is more common in adults and is often linked to secondary causes like autoimmune diseases or infections. The normal blood pressure and serum creatinine in this child, along with the absence of secondary causes, make membranous nephropathy unlikely. The age and laboratory findings favor a diagnosis more typical in pediatric populations.

B) CORRECT:

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, presenting with significant proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia, leading to periorbital and pedal edema. The laboratory findings of marked proteinuria and low serum albumin result from altered glomerular filtration due to effacement of podocyte foot processes. Light microscopy may appear normal, but electron microscopy reveals this effacement. The preserved renal function and normal blood pressure in this patient align with the typical presentation of minimal change disease in pediatric patients, where selective protein loss primarily causes hypoalbuminemia and decreased plasma oncotic pressure, resulting in edema.

Key learning point: Nephrotic syndrome in children is characterized by significant proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema, and is the most common cause of these symptoms in this age group.

C) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) typically affects older children and adults, often presenting with hypertension and impaired renal function. This patient, however, has normal blood pressure and serum creatinine levels, which are inconsistent with FSGS. Additionally, FSGS is associated with risk factors such as obesity and infections, which are not present here.

D) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy usually presents with hematuria, often following upper respiratory infections, rather than significant proteinuria. This patient exhibits heavy proteinuria and low serum albumin, indicative of a nephrotic process, not typically seen in IgA nephropathy. The absence of hematuria and presence of generalized edema further exclude IgA nephropathy.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can present with nephrotic syndrome features, but it typically affects older children or adults and often involves hypertension or renal impairment. This patient is 7 years old, has normal blood pressure, and lacks features like steroid resistance or significant hematuria, making FSGS unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

This 7-year-old boy's presentation of periorbital and peripheral edema, along with laboratory findings of significant proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hypercholesterolemia, aligns with nephrotic syndrome. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. It involves T-cell mediated cytokine release, disrupting podocyte architecture and causing foot process effacement, visible only on electron microscopy. The selective albumin loss due to increased glomerular permeability results in low serum albumin and compensatory hypercholesterolemia.

Key learning point: In children presenting with nephrotic syndrome characterized by significant proteinuria and edema, Minimal Change Disease is the most common cause and should be considered as the likely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) often presents as a nephritic-nephrotic syndrome with significant hematuria and hypertension due to immune complex deposition. This patient has normal blood pressure and rare erythrocytes in urine, which do not align with MPGN's typical inflammatory profile. Additionally, MPGN is associated with complement abnormalities, not indicated here.

D) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy is more common in adults and involves subepithelial immune complex deposition. It is often linked to secondary causes like hepatitis or malignancies, which are not suggested in this young child. The patient's age and lack of associated risk factors make this diagnosis less likely.

He recently had a mild upper respiratory tract infection but has otherwise been healthy. He has no history of similar episodes, and there is no known family history of renal disease. He reports no abdominal pain or gross hematuria. Growth parameters are normal, and he has no hearing difficulties. Physical examination shows puffy eyelids and mild bilateral pedal edema (see lab results).

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis usually presents with nephritic syndrome features, including significant hematuria, hypertension, and elevated creatinine. The presence of marked proteinuria, low serum albumin, and normal blood pressure indicates a nephrotic rather than nephritic state, making this diagnosis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Minimal change disease manifests in children with periorbital and pedal edema, significant proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia. It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and often follows an upper respiratory tract infection. The condition involves T cell-mediated damage to podocytes, leading to effacement of foot processes and increased glomerular permeability. Light microscopy typically appears normal, while electron microscopy reveals podocyte changes. The selective albuminuria results in decreased plasma oncotic pressure, causing edema.

Key learning point: Nephrotic syndrome in children is characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema, often following a recent infection, and is commonly due to minimal change disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) causes significant proteinuria and edema but is more common in adolescents and adults. It often presents with hypertension and declining renal function, which are absent here. The acute onset and recent infection history are more consistent with minimal change disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy, characterized by subepithelial immune complex deposition, typically affects adults. Although it causes proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia, the patient's age and recent infection suggest a more common pediatric nephrotic syndrome, such as minimal change disease.

Examination shows notable periorbital and pedal edema (see lab results).

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by subepithelial immune complex deposition and thickened capillary walls, typically affecting older children and adults. It often develops gradually and may involve low complement levels or risk factors like autoimmune diseases, which are not present here. The acute onset and age of the patient make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) often presents with nephrotic syndrome but is more common in older children and adults. It frequently involves hematuria, hypertension, or declining renal function, which are absent here. FSGS is also associated with secondary causes or a gradual progression, not seen in this acute presentation.

C) CORRECT:

Minimal change disease is the leading cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. It manifests with heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema due to podocyte foot process effacement, which disrupts the glomerular filtration barrier. The absence of hematuria, normal complement levels, and preserved renal function align with this diagnosis. Unlike other nephrotic syndromes, minimal change disease does not involve immune complex deposition, explaining the normal complement levels. Electron microscopy typically reveals effacement of podocyte foot processes, while light microscopy appears normal or shows minimal changes.

Key learning point: Minimal Change Disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, characterized by sudden onset of edema and proteinuria.

D) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) usually presents with mixed nephritic-nephrotic syndrome, including hematuria and low complement levels due to immune complex deposition. The absence of hematuria, normal complement levels, and lack of nephritic features make MPGN an improbable diagnosis in this context.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man presents with increased swelling in both legs and shortness of breath when lying flat for the past two weeks. He has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes and stage 4 chronic kidney disease with an estimated GFR of 20 mL/min/1.73 m^2. He is on a low-sodium diet and takes a thiazide diuretic for blood pressure control. Physical examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure, a displaced apical impulse, and 2+ pitting edema up to the mid-calf. After modest relief with sodium restriction, he continues to experience fluid overload (see lab result).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Creatinine
300 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing his edema?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD), particularly with an estimated glomerular filtration rate (GFR) below 30 mL/min/1.73 m2, thiazide diuretics are less effective due to their reliance on adequate renal function for delivery to the distal convoluted tubule. Loop diuretics, however, act on the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, providing effective natriuresis and fluid removal even with reduced renal function. The intravenous route enhances their efficacy by ensuring rapid onset and bypassing gastrointestinal absorption. This is crucial for managing volume overload, as evidenced by elevated jugular venous pressure, orthopnea, and peripheral edema in this patient.

Key learning point: In patients with significant renal impairment and edema, thiazide diuretics are less effective, and loop diuretics like furosemide are preferred for managing fluid overload.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous albumin is used for edema due to hypoalbuminemia, such as in liver disease or nephrotic syndrome. This patient's edema is due to volume overload from CKD, not low oncotic pressure. Albumin infusion could exacerbate intravascular volume, stressing the cardiovascular system further.

C) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone, a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist, can cause hyperkalemia, especially in advanced CKD where potassium excretion is impaired. Its diuretic effect is modest compared to loop diuretics, making it unsuitable for significant volume overload in this patient with reduced renal function.

D) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics act on the distal convoluted tubule and require adequate renal function for delivery. In advanced CKD with a GFR of 20 mL/min/1.73 m2, their effectiveness is significantly reduced. Increasing the dose would not substantially enhance diuresis and could lead to adverse effects without overcoming the limitations of reduced renal function.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents for follow-up. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and was started on a new medication three months ago for blood pressure control and renal protection after trace albuminuria was detected. Since starting the medication, he has developed a persistent dry cough that began two weeks later. Physical examination is normal (see lab result).


Heart rate
82/min


Blood pressure
150/92 mm Hg




Test
Result
Normal Values

115 μmol/L
